We should've known how bad the next forza motorsport would be after how badly designed the menus in this game are. I don't know how to navigate half of the tabs in the pause menu. A main thing i realized after playing for a while is that this game doesn't teach you the basics of forza, it expects you to understand the PI system even though this is my first forza game. It has been a long a while since i've played the 'tutorial' of this game, but I have a feeling that there isnt much of one if theirs players who don't know how to even upgrade and stay in a class. From my perspective, even if I haven't played other forza games, I think they just took the good simcadey handling model from previous forza's and did things half way with everything else. I don't know any of the npcs names in this game, I can't name any of them. There is essentially no story, bad menu design, small open world, dull car engine sounds, and an inconsistent, unrewarding, slot machine system that doesn't inspire getting better over time, but handing the newbies a hypercar without teaching them how to understand it. The only thing that is keeping me going is the good handling and I can bet that i could find better if it wasn't for the fact that there are so few rewarding, well made, decently running, simple graphics, racing games made nowadays. Go play GT4

EDIT: Got screwed over by the developer. Why would they release FH4 when they were getting ready to release FH5 within a year? I wasted ~$60 of my steam wallet for the premium edition and that was on sale. I will NEVER buy another Forza game on steam because of this. I have the information on the release dates and my purchase here:

-So, release of FH4: 3-9-2021
-I purchased Premium Ed. on: 4-8-2021
-FH5 released: 11-8-2021
-Support for FH4 ended: 9-27-2022

-Gypped ~$60 for a game I was able to play for about a year. Never again

One of my favourite "simcade" racers ever. I played it to death via the Microsoft Store, and having the chance to replay it via the Steam version has been a dream come true for me.

Honestly, I prefer this to the sequel in several ways. Forza Horizon 5 is beautiful in its own way, but it also ironically feels TOO big and empty. FH4's map is just right, and a lot more dynamic, especially with how dramatically the seasons change the map and the driving. There's a feeling this game captures that few racing/driving games have managed to capture, as you tear through the Scottish countryside and the streets of Edinburgh in your favourite car, music playing on the radio as autumn leaves whip around you. It's just an absolute pleasure to play.

Problems? Yeah, a couple. Sometimes, the AI on anything above the Average difficulty will choose at least one racer to be a "Peter Perfect", pulling ahead to the point it becomes more difficult to catch up than it should be (though to nowhere near the same egregious level as FH5 or Forza Motorsport 2023). Also some of the Quality-of-Life changes made in FH5, such as the ability to sell or donate duplicate cars immediately upon receiving them, are sorely missed. Also sometimes the Wheelspin's rewards are beyond a joke, but massive credit goes to the developers for not shoving in microtransactions.

EDIT 21/2/24: It turns out you CAN immediately sell duplicate cars if you win them via the Wheelspin. I honestly don't remember that feature being there before; maybe they added it in an update?

Forza Horizon 4 is just brilliant, in ways both tangible and intangible. Beautiful graphically and a ton of fun to play, along with the feeling of simple joy it gives the player through just driving and exploring. To me, this is as good as these sorts of racing games can possibly be.

Back in my school days, before the internet and smartphones were a thing, there was this guy in our class, Bobby, who was selling pages from adult magazines. 
I think he was getting them from his older brother or his Pops. Cutting them precisely so that he doesn't notice a page missing.
Each Monday he refreshed his stash and we were so excited to get to school just to see what he has.
Sometimes he would have Pam A or other classics and he had to host an auction, man, cause everyone wanted to have it.
I tell you, he was popular. We would just cash out our daily allowance with a smile and fold that picture neatly in a textbook put it in our backpack and oh man, it would turn in to a JET PACK.
You'd be going back home after a bad grade and just wouldn't care you are getting grounded, cause you know you are bringing gold or you can dig out one of the classics from your stash and have a blast.

That's how booting up this game at the end of the day feels like.
Fun game, just wish it didnt take place in england.

If you are looking for a racing game with an amazing atmosphere and views without reducing the sensation of racing itself, I think this is the right game for you. The city views are quite stunning to explore, there is a large collection of cars that you can try, and there are many things you can explore when doing roaming (free-roam). For me, the racing itself also unique because it presents various types of races such as track races, city races, offroad races, rally races and drag strip races. The only drawback is the Auction feature, where users can only auction a maximum of 20 cars, it's not a big problem for me in fact, maybe in the future the number of car auctions can be increased. 
- Overall 9/10 -

I've been able to get a handful of hours in and can give a more balanced review now.

For those who enjoy an "arcady" racing game, Forza Horizon 4 does a good job.  There are multiple view angles for the car.  Handling has a classic arcade style.  Tuning is not overdone, and you can buy user developed templates for the cost of parts.  The normal racing styles (on and off road) are available.  There is a good selection of cars to earn as you work your way through.

On the downside, there are non-racing interface issues.  I may have missed something, but it appears that there are no private servers, so juveniles, or juvenile adults, can harass you by blocking your view when they drive into your car's space.  Progression between seasons is too fast and can be earned with non-racing accomplishments alone.  Every time you login, it insists on asking you to link your MS and Steam accounts...loading times are too long, especially the introductory movie.

This is an older game, but not worth the price MS asks for it, even on sale...I'd go $10 USD if I could do it again.  I'll probably get a bit of entertainment out of it, but not what I paid on a sale.

My overall review hasn't changed.  I cannot recommend this game unless you are a die hard arcade racing fanatic.  For those who prefer other genres and just want an occasional race, there are better options at better prices.
--------------------
As I write this review, I have half-an-hour of "game play" recorded.  That is how long it took to get logged into a MS account.  MS is their own worst enemy.
I cannot in good conscience recommend this game if you have any complications logging into MS, such as if your account and your child's account are linked through something like an Xbox.
I wish that I could talk about the game content, but I haven't been able to get there yet, and I need to put this game away and calm down after the nightmare of a login process.
Best driving physics of any modern arcade game.

For a casual-ish gamer like me (= not looking for a complete simulation experience, using a keyboard or a regular controller at most) overall, a satisfactory game. Car brand/model diversity is sufficient - even though it's sort of a DLC hell; sales are abundant, so you may easily grab it with a good discount (good price even without a discount thanks to FH5) and from what i've heard; it's better optimized and more player-friendly compared to Forza Horizon 5. Car upgrade and tuning mechanics might be better balanced but enough for an arcade-y simulation, i believe. Haven't tried the Fortune Island yet but i found the LEGO DLC unnecessary, just a waste of my hard drive space, really.

Good game: 7.5/10
very fun. fh5 is just barely better tho if this one is cheaper at the moment then get this one :)

This is a game, not a simulation.  If you want a kiddie game without damage, ignoring the laws of physics, and don't mind being programmed to become a reckless driver without empathy for others on the road, this is for you.  If you are looking for an actual simulation, get Assetto Corsi series programs.  As a former trauma nurse and EMT, I shudder to think what we teach young kids about car driving and crashes with games like this; its only slightly better than desensitizing people with FPS games.   If I were I driver's education instructor, I'd likely picket the game studio.

A nice, full-featured and beautiful open world arcade racer with hundreds of great cars, plagued only by the typical issues of AAA games these days: tons of DLCs, useless cosmetics, always online, and a mainstream presentation for western pubers, slippery as an eel. If you can live with that, it's a good arcade racer.

Pros:
* great open world, a beautiful interpretation of a mini version of the UK
* the scenery changes depending on the season (e.g., lakes freeze and you can drive over them in winter), which is awesome
* lots of content: tons of races, cars, and things to explore
* tons of settings, customization options
* there are different types of events (rally, cross country, street racing, ...) and nothing forces you into doing something you do not want to do. Real freedom! It's an open world that deserves the name, not just a boring map which replaces the main menu!

Cons:
* Annoying UI and menus
* The typical AAA game disadvantages these days: more DLCs and editions than you can count, and even if you buy the ultimate, there is still stuff for that they charge you extra.
* Presentation (always happy rich kid car festival crowd, main characters considers himself the coolest dude on earth, the music the loading screen animation of people cheering at you on stage with your car) is clearly aimed at pubers and feels borderline cringeworthy to me
* events (the races you start from the open world) are very short, typically about 3 minutes
* It does (almost) not matter whether you drive on the road or not, you have similar grip and speed in the woods and you can just drive through almost everything, even medium sized trees will just disappear in a falling tree animation and a minor sound effect without even reducing your speed. This means people drive everywhere and its often faster to go in a straight line rather than follow the roads, which can kill a lot of the immersion. You can even go through major rivers.
* bad mainstream pop music. In general, it feels like they wanted to please everyone a bit too much.

Neutral:
* It's clearly advertised as an arcade racer so I will not count this as a negative, but if you try to race with all assists off and manual shifting, you will find that this makes little sense: there are tons of races, each on different tracks, and you do not know the corners, so you need the racing line if you want to be fast. Also it's hard to turn off the rewind feature: because you can just drive next to the road (see above), races use checkpoints every 300 meters that you have to go through, and missing one means your position is reset and you lose a lot of time and have to restart. The solution if you missed one by accident is of course the rewind feature. And in the cross-country races, where you are sliding at high speed through the landscape with very little control, you will miss checkpoints sooner or later. This game is definitely a lot more about finishing hundreds of short races in hundreds of cars than about properly learning a few tracks and cars.
* Does not work with my new Fanatec wheel and paddles, they are not detected at all even though they work in ACC and Dirt 2. But as this could be a problem with the latest Fanatec driver according to forums, I am for now listing it as neutral instead of negative.


Overall 8/10 if you are looking for an arcade open world racing game to play with a controller. Just don't expect something too serious.

It's a pity they can't produce a world like this for more serious racing games with a smaller audience. But I'm a software developer and I can tell that this was definitely [b]not[/b] a low budget project. Forza 5 is a copy of this game where they replaced the UK map with Mexico, btw. I have both, and I slightly prefer 4, but it's just about the map.

Forza Horizon 4 for me is a really fun Racing game and i think it's even a bit better than Forza Horizon 5.

FH4 for me has better map Quality even though it smaller than Empty and boring FH5's map, because in FH4 The map is actually filled with something and someplace can be really good looking, even Edinburgh map in this game is actually pretty accurate from a part of Edinburgh in real life.

FH4 also has Ranked Racing and a pretty good DLCs (Fortune Island and LEGO DLC) not like FH5 that doesn't have Ranked Racing and only 1 Good DLC (Rally Adventure).

Overall, Forza Horizon 4 is very recommended if you want to try Forza Horizon/Racing series because it has good map and good content. But remember that Forza Horizon 4 is not getting anymore new content (unless Festival Playlist Update / Monthly challenges if you don't know what Festival playlist is).

Finally, a good racing game! The devs really put some work into this. 

For years, I've had to deal with crap racing titles that start off easy enough, but amp up the difficulty exponentially as you progress through the game to the point where it's literally impossible to win a race. Thankfully, that isn't the case here; it's challenging, but not insanely difficult. There are plenty of activities including street racing, off road racing, drifting, jumps, stunt driving, (online, LAN, or solo) and more. 

I enjoyed the environments and the extensive collection of vehicles. Great visual and mechanical customization, too. 

10/10!

This was my first experience with a Forza game, and I was very impressed!  Being a Brit, I was curious to see how they'd distilled the country into the the game world and found that they'd done an awesome job.  You drive seamlessly from the Cotswolds to the Lake District and on up into Scotland.  I loved just driving around and taking in the scenery.

Of course, I also got hooked on the various Horizon races, of which there are great variety, from road races to cross-country events.  There's also a huge number of vehicles to acquire for your garage, including some great British classics.  Didn't do too much with the multiplayer aspects of the game, but it was fun to see others driving around in the same game world and I did try a few multiplayer races.

I have played both FH4 and FH5 along with Crew Motorfest, NFS Unbound.

For me the ranking would be like:
1. Crew Motorfest
2. FH 4
3. NFS Unbound
4. FH 5

This game in particular I liked a lot due to these reasons:
1. Better setting than FH5. It feels more calming and soothing. The only reason I will play FH5 instead of this is cause of friends or more cars.
2. I like the seasons mechanism


CONS:
1. The races don't feel legit. The AI feels like cheating with a huge down force. The issue is continued in the FH5.
2. Can't control the weather. Once again the issue continues on FH5.


Overall a really good game. The graphics hold their own even after all these year.

Totally recommended on sale.

Still good fun though; there's no experience like taking a romp around Scotland in a '50s Peel going 130 miles an hour.

[h1]DO NOT GET THIS GAME ON STEAM[/h1]
Amazing game, but I do NOT recommend getting it on Steam, because the trigger rumble on the Xbox controller does not work. (Rumble does work but the specific rumble inside the triggers does not work.) Without this it is a lot harder to get a feel of your car.  
It has been 3 years and this well known issue is not fixed and will never be fixed.

Do yourself a favor and get the game on the microsoft store instead, and enjoy Great Britain in its full glory.

Але Майкрософт дуже всрато зробили онлайн аспект: часті вильоти, з друзями іноді не можемо нормально створити паті щоб норм поганяти, бо вічні помилки та вильоти з лобі; після перевстановлення або іноді просто так, гра відмовляється входити в акк, розлогінює, не зчитує нормально сейв. Ще тупий аспект - гра не піде на неповноцінній вінді типу LTSB чи вінді без оболонки MS Store.
Ще не завжди коректно працює з рулем. тобто працює, але відвалюється вібрація. Доводиться просто вимикати та вмикати руль в юсб щоб запрацювало

Forza Horizon 4 is an adrenaline-fueled masterpiece that immerses players in the exhilarating world of open-world racing. Set in a stunningly recreated Britain, this game offers an unparalleled experience for both casual players and hardcore racing enthusiasts alike.

Graphics and Sound:
Visually, Forza Horizon 4 is a feast for the eyes. The attention to detail in the environments, weather effects, and car models is simply breathtaking. Whether you're racing through the lush countryside or tearing up the streets of Edinburgh, every moment feels incredibly lifelike. Accompanied by a dynamic soundtrack that perfectly complements the on-screen action, the audiovisual experience of Forza Horizon 4 is nothing short of spectacular.

Gameplay:
The gameplay in Forza Horizon 4 strikes a perfect balance between accessibility and depth. From the moment you hit the accelerator, you're treated to responsive controls and a smooth driving experience. Whether you prefer to tackle the extensive single-player campaign, compete in online multiplayer races, or simply explore the vast open world at your own pace, there's no shortage of content to keep you entertained for hours on end.

Dynamic Seasons:
One of the standout features of Forza Horizon 4 is its dynamic weather system, which introduces four distinct seasons that not only affect the visuals but also dramatically alter the gameplay. From racing through the snow in winter to navigating rain-soaked roads in spring, each season presents its own set of challenges and opportunities, ensuring that no two races ever feel the same.

Customization and Progression:
With a vast array of cars to collect, customize, and upgrade, Forza Horizon 4 offers endless opportunities for personalization and progression. Whether you're a fan of classic muscle cars, high-performance exotics, or off-road behemoths, there's a vehicle to suit every taste and playstyle. Combine this with the ability to fine-tune your cars to perfection and the deep progression system that rewards skill and dedication, and you have a game that keeps you coming back for more.

Conclusion:
In summary, Forza Horizon 4 is a triumph of open-world racing, offering stunning visuals, exhilarating gameplay, and a wealth of content to explore. Whether you're a seasoned racing veteran or a newcomer to the genre, this game delivers an unforgettable experience that is sure to leave you craving more. Strap in, rev your engines, and get ready for the ride of a lifetime. Forza Horizon 4 is an absolute must-play for any racing fan.

Forza Horizon 4 is an exhilarating open-world racing experience set in the picturesque landscapes of Britain. With an extensive roster of cars, dynamic weather, and seasons that change the environment, every race feels fresh and exciting. The attention to detail is staggering, from the breathtaking scenery to the realistic car physics. The seamless online integration allows for cooperative and competitive play, adding depth to the already captivating gameplay. Forza Horizon 4 is a masterpiece of the racing genre, offering endless hours of adrenaline-fueled fun for players of all skill levels.

This is my Forza Horizon 4 review, so let's get into the positives about the game, it's a really fun open world racing game with lots to keep you occupied within the world itself such as collectibles, lots of cars, upgrades and customization options, as well as tons of events of varying things to do. 

Not everything is strictly just racing, there's tons of other fun modes online as well like eliminator and things to do such as daily and weekly challenges with rewards to keep you engaged. You can even buy your own house in game and customize your character even with lots of cosmetic items, so there isn't a lot of expression in this game with the amount of options at your disposal.

Last but not least they even have a story mode split into chapters which reminds me a bit of the GTA missions.

Now onto the negatives that I personally have gripes with in the game, the DLC pop ups! If you only own the base game, the game will nag you pretty often with "ad" type cinematics that you can't skip after certain events and stuff and it doesn't just do this once, it does it constantly, when you just wanna get back into the open world and race it's pretty annoying. 

The music you can't shut off is pretty annoying as well, you can shut it off via streamer mode but it's still always on the loading screens, they should've had an option to turn it off completely.

Lastly the difficulty pop ups, when you're either winning or losing a certain amount of times, it'll ask you if you want to lower or raise your difficulty level, this I found to be intrusive because when I set a difficulty level I'd like to just leave it, not have it keep nagging me.

Overall it's a pretty decent racing game with lots to do, despite it's negatives I'll still be playing it because it's super fun and the positives far outweigh the negatives, so if you like open world racing games with tons to do and lots of customization, I highly suggest picking it up, final score is an 8/10 for me.

Forza Horizon 4 is a racing game that lets you explore a beautiful open world in Britain, with over 450 cars to collect and customize. The game also features dynamic seasons, online multiplayer, and cross-play with Xbox One and Windows 10 players. However, the game is plagued by a serious issue on PC: it crashes constantly.

The game crashes at random times, sometimes during loading screens, sometimes during races, sometimes during cutscenes, and sometimes even before the game starts. The game does not give any error message or explanation for the crashes, it just closes abruptly and returns to the desktop. This makes the game unplayable and frustrating, as you lose your progress and achievements.

The game's developers, Playground Games, have not provided any official solution or patch for the crashing problem, despite the numerous complaints and reports from PC players. The game's forums and Steam discussions are filled with people asking for help and sharing their experiences with the crashes. Some players have tried various methods to fix the crashes, such as updating drivers, lowering graphics settings, disabling antivirus, verifying game files, and reinstalling the game, but none of them seem to work for everyone.

The game's crashing problem is unacceptable and disappointing, especially for a game that costs $59.99 (For India INR 1299) and has been out for more than two years. The game should have been tested and optimized for PC before its release, or at least patched afterwards. The game is a waste of money and time for PC players, and it should be avoided until the developers fix it or offer a refund.

Forza Horizon 4, developed by Playground Games and published by Microsoft Studios, is an exceptional addition to the Forza Horizon series. Released in October 2018, this open-world racing game has garnered widespread acclaim for its stunning visuals, diverse range of vehicles, dynamic weather system, and engaging gameplay.

One of the standout features of Forza Horizon 4 is its breathtaking recreation of a fictional version of Great Britain. The attention to detail is remarkable, with picturesque landscapes, charming villages, and iconic landmarks seamlessly integrated into the game world. The changing seasons add a dynamic element to the environment, affecting not only the aesthetics but also the driving dynamics. Racing through the same route in different seasons provides a refreshing and varied experience, as snow, rain, and sunshine each impact the handling of vehicles in distinct ways.

The vehicle roster in Forza Horizon 4 is extensive and diverse, featuring a wide array of cars from various manufacturers spanning different eras. Whether you're a fan of classic muscle cars, sleek supercars, or off-road beasts, there's something for everyone. The attention to detail in the car models is outstanding, with realistic interiors and authentic engine sounds that enhance the overall immersion.

The gameplay mechanics are accessible to both casual players and hardcore racing enthusiasts. The handling of cars strikes a good balance between realism and fun, making it easy for newcomers to pick up and play, while still offering depth for those seeking a more realistic driving experience. The open-world setting encourages exploration, and there are numerous events and challenges scattered throughout the map, ensuring that players always have something to do.

Forza Horizon 4's multiplayer component adds another layer of excitement to the experience. The seamless integration of online features allows players to seamlessly transition between solo and multiplayer modes, and the shared world creates a dynamic environment where other players can appear in your game at any time. The Horizon Life system ties together single-player and multiplayer progression, offering a cohesive experience as you level up and unlock new content.

The graphics in Forza Horizon 4 are nothing short of spectacular. The level of detail in the environments, the realistic lighting, and the weather effects contribute to a visually stunning racing experience. Whether you're racing through a forest in autumn or navigating snowy roads in winter, the visuals never fail to impress.

The soundtrack is another standout element, featuring a diverse selection of music that caters to different tastes. The radio stations offer a mix of genres, and the ability to create a custom playlist from your own music library adds a personal touch to the audio experience.

In conclusion, Forza Horizon 4 is a masterpiece in the racing genre. Its attention to detail, stunning visuals, diverse vehicle roster, dynamic weather system, and engaging gameplay make it a must-play for any racing game enthusiast. Whether you're a casual player looking for fun or a dedicated racer seeking a realistic driving experience, Forza Horizon 4 delivers on all fronts, solidifying its place as one of the best open-world racing games to date.

Forza Horizon 4 is an absolute masterpiece of a racing game that sets a new standard for the genre. From the moment you hit the roads of beautiful, historic Britain, you're immersed in an exhilarating world of automotive excitement.

One of the most impressive aspects of Forza Horizon 4 is its stunning visuals. The attention to detail in the environments, from the rolling countryside to the bustling city streets, is nothing short of breathtaking. Each season brings its own unique charm, with dynamic weather effects that not only look incredible but also affect gameplay in exciting ways.

The car lineup in Forza Horizon 4 is second to none. With hundreds of meticulously modeled vehicles spanning various eras and disciplines, there's something for every type of car enthusiast. Whether you're tearing through off-road trails in a rugged 4x4, dominating the track in a high-performance supercar, or cruising along the coastline in a classic muscle car, the selection is unparalleled.

The driving mechanics are perfectly tuned, striking a balance between accessibility and depth. Whether you're a seasoned racing veteran or a casual player, you'll find the handling to be responsive and satisfying. The addition of the Horizon Life online mode adds a new layer of excitement, allowing you to connect with friends and compete in a variety of challenges and events.

But perhaps the most impressive aspect of Forza Horizon 4 is its sheer amount of content. The world is filled with activities to discover, from exhilarating races and daring stunts to hidden treasures and photo opportunities. With each new season, the landscape transforms, keeping the experience fresh and exciting long after you've crossed the finish line.

In conclusion, Forza Horizon 4 is a triumph of game design that delivers an unparalleled racing experience. With its breathtaking visuals, extensive car lineup, polished mechanics, and wealth of content, it's a must-have title for any racing fan. Whether you're tearing up the track solo or tearing through the countryside with friends, Forza Horizon 4 never fails to impress.

Putting it into simple points:
1. The game has a lot of unskippable cutscenes, some that introduce the background "story" (if you can even call it that), some that just show new available events on the map (which are mostly just talking over a static image of the map). Moreover, some of these cutscenes are ads for the DLC, which last quite a while. 
2. Time wasting mechanics: to name the most annoying one - the fast travel. What do you mean, isn't it supposed to save you time? It is, but at first it is limited to only a few spots, and it costs more than you earn  for a single race... You can lower the cost of it to 0 if you find all the travel boards, but searching them up (looking up the location on the internet) takes around 3 hours of just that :\ 
3. Unnecessary bloat: in this game you have your own character, for which you can buy clothes, gestures etc. I wouldn't mind that, but it feels like the game is flooding you with this stuff instead of giving you rewards that really matter (like new cars). 
4. A lot of the better rewards come from gacha mechanics. 
5. Annoying bugs: The most frequent one is the map not displaying some of the icons after some new events are being introduced, which does not improve till you restart the game. 
6. Rewards from races are unsatisfying - maybe it's because of me being at the early stages of the game, but the races usually give between 6-12 thousand CR, with some cars and houses going for millions. If they do not improve with time, the grind to get them will be excruciating. (you can boost the rewards slightly by increasing the difficulty, but it is % based, so can't expect much)
7. Heavy pushing monetization - with not only DLC cars (which I am actually ok with), but for example the map marking all the boards to collect. Just why?

The core gameplay is great, but all the bloat and bad rewards structure do not make me want to play this game more. I will give it another few hours, but at this point I am wondering if it will be worth it.

UPDATED REVIEW:
"It's up and working again!"

If you are on AMD, and the program stops working/starts memory leaking; go to your root FH4 folder and delete "TargetHardwareProfiler.dll". After that's deleted, the game should work again as normal.

This game goes beyond what its mainstay console competitors have. Games like Need For Speed have their place here too, but the newer games feel far more limited in their options. FH4 has a much larger list of cars, some of which have been ported and touched up from previous games. The large multiplayer open world ensures you'll pass by some players. Cars have liveries, which means you can get pretty close to some real life car paint jobs or even make your own. The four seasons can be finicky for some, but personally I think this works out. The only real inconvenience with seasons is Winter, but you just need to slap on some Winter tires and you'll be fine. Regardless, I highly recommend to people who enjoy just driving around big areas. England is pretty cool too, I guess.

Yes I struggle with words when I am expressing myself.

I bought this FH 4 UK from Steam.

FH5 is too easy? its got more grip and you just put on Power mods and go FAST! the map is boring. This map is gorgeous. its got corners and corners and corners. Yes I know my word salad is possibly too late, people may have already moved on, the world is waiting for a new Horizon DIG with not as much abated breathe since FH 5 was ummmm recycled crabs basically.

[h1] I recommend this game and the entire Forza Horizon series as the best racing game of nowadays, and maybe even as the best game and series ever. [/h1] 

[i] At the time of writing the review, there were only 5 parts [/i]

Recommended for everyone who misses the old days of NFS and those who are not familiar with racing games, but want to give it a try. This game is exactly what a real racing game should be and will bring pleasure to both professionals and hoary racers as well as beginners who are afraid that they will not be able to compete in the race.

Good control, intuitive behavior of the car (exactly what you expect happens), an open world (which can be rammed or destroyed almost entirely and nothing will stop you. almost...), variable tuning of the car (both appearance and performance) graphics and optimization, what else is needed for a perfect racing game.

Also, multiplayer (to ride with friends or with strangers), constant events every week with cool rewards, roulette for which you don't have to pay, just play and win new cars and other great prizes.

And, of course, the change of season, which changes the game beyond recognition.

[h2]10/10 [/h2]

[h3]  PS. [/h3] [b] It is recommended to play on a gamepad, but it is also normal to play on the keyboard. [/b]

My first Forza Horizon game ever and honestly, the only thing that really has this game going for me is the graphics, that's it. I took the time to learn to love the game but there is always something that triggers me every single time I play the game. First off the menu selection, to put it simply, it's confusing. It could have just been a simple selection like a list style menu without having to memorize everything due to the fact that its squares in each tab, and each time you select a square you get another screen menu which has a bunch of squares again making it really visually difficult and confusing. Same thing applies when you try to join races online, I'm aware there are not many players in this game compared to when it came out but why can't we have a open menu to see or filter lobbies created for a specific type of race rather than trying join randomly until getting the race you want, it's so frustrating, it's like the game was designed to be a headache. The only option you have is basically is to filter and search for races then good luck finding a race. The vinyl editor could have been way better considering the game has amazing graphics. Now with the tuning, I just wish there was more information that what you get from the tuning menu and telemetry, this would've made it easier to tune the cars rather than relying on a test drive every single time you make a setup change. Race physics seems funny except for when conditions are dry, in some cases like on a snowy or wet road, gravel or dirt you get pretty inconsistent results driving around the car, and I'm not talking about the conditions or terrain, it's the responsiveness of the car to that, now you can say that's exactly what it is but then what's the point of tuning? There are a variety of events to choose from but it doesn't feel like there's enough street and road racing events, after completing The Marathon and (I think)The Gauntlet I was left unsatisfied looking for more. Maybe it's just my expectations getting in the way of me enjoying the game, but I just really can't see it that way.

Don't buy the steam version, it's a bad port with broken controller support and doesn't transfer save files, tunes, nor liveries. I have since gotten a new "supported" wheel that still doesn't function correctly, refuses to bind my handbrake, and the FFB is still broken. I've since tried it on a buddy's system with the Windows Store version and everything works fine. I'm now debating buying the MS version to have it at least be functional, but then I basically have to start the entire game over again since it won't transfer save data on the same account.

The worst Horizon, and wheel support is basically completely broken. It also doesn't do cross saves, despite being tied to the same MS account, so all of the previous progress I've made and paint schemes from old titles I just can't access, which is just... incredible really. It also frequently gets stuck in infinite load loops after restarting an event, and initial bootup can take longer than GTAV for no reason. Sometimes it's quick, sometimes it's minutes.

Not my choice of the Horizon games. As the series has gone on the maps have just gotten worse to actually drive on. Being that I don't own an Xbox, the only alternative is Horizon 3 which has been removed from sale, I was stuck with this. I don't know what possessed the team to think that Britain would be a good location for Horizon. It's the most boring map yet offering a vast landscape of mostly empty flower fields. It's by far the least diverse map and the only thought to be had about that is they added seasons, but 3 of 4 are just variations of textures and frequency of rain. No one likes winter. As time has gone on in the series the roads have gotten wider and straighter so the lower class cars are a snore to drive. Even some of the super cars can bring on a snore when you go flat out through 4 corners in a row with hardly any steering input.

The game also never shuts up. After just about every race you get inundated with heaps of characters taking control away from you for unskippable cutscenes or dialogue you don't care about. The game won't even let you actually mute them, or the radio to play your own music for that matter. I'm 17,5 hours in and it still feels like I'm in a tutorial. It's a racing game, it's not that complicated.

They also destroyed any sense of progression Within the first few hours you're swimming in multi-million dollar cars, playing the slot machines to win more... or maybe just some really dumb clothing and dances.

One of the biggest things to me is I'm a huge loser and have a toy steering wheel. Despite the fact that my wheel is officially supported, and the game also supports multiple USB devices, it didn't recognize my pedals. Turns out this is a day 1 issue they never fixed. This started a full 2 day long troubleshooting process of using third party apps, conversing with devs of said app, registry edits, testing, etc. I eventually got it "working," but the FFB is so completely different from every other game with wheel support ever. That's not an exaggeration. The Crew has better wheel support than this, despite having much worse physics. There's a pretty huge deadzone in centering forces for the first ~90 degrees of rotation left and right, which is where 95% of your driving actually is, thus I can't tell what the car is doing or how much grip I have until it's gone and sliding. If I drive down the highway at 90mph, turn the wheel 90 left and let go, it just stays there. It doesn't even attempt to center. None of the FFB settings fix this, and I can't figure out if it's just me.
In an effort to play by their rules, I dug through my box o crap and got the cable to plug my pedals into my wheel base, which should've been officially supported. The brake and throttle pedal were switched, with the button bindings being non-existent or illogical. Even when I play by their rules it's broken. I feel like I should get a refund on principle, but there's no way Steam would let me now because I spent 2 days trying to troubleshoot it.

I decided on Forza 4 to satisfy my Off Road "WreckFest" style itch. It has a bit of everything and the seasonal track changes are pretty cool too. I'm only a couple hours into it, but so far I'm digging the game. It definitely pats you on the head for almost everything you do while driving. "Great burnout!"... "Way to trash that fence" (We know you meant to do that. Here's some points!!") As with any driving game, it takes a couple trips around the track to get the feel for the driving attributes but is very forgiving on the KB. So far its run flawlessly, no issues at all. It's a different beast with a Wheel.

You do have to have a Microsoft login account to even start the game unfortunately. I don't like that trend and I wished they'd stop doing that crap but they didn't bother me again once I remembered my Login and password.

As with any driving game, it takes a couple trips around the track to get the feel for the driving attributes.  KB controls are definitely doable, albeit a little soft and a tad sluggish but I guess that's to be expected. Each car I've driven so far, feels different to dive, as it should be. I knew cornering was going to be a challenge with my meaty Dodge Charger but i'm an old school racer that likes to catch those rice burners on the straightaways. Works great with my Logitech wheel and pedal setup.
  
Visuals are pretty good. I can run the game in ultra with my AMD Ryzen7 5800X and  8MB NVIDIA RTX3060Ti GPU.
The game starts with a very nice bench test if you want too. 

Music is OK for an hour or so. After that, I turned it down and streamed my own playlist. (ACDC and some Nugent BTW) 

I LOVE Anna's GPS directions. Haven't heard her in an actual race yet but its nice getting to the next race or influence spot anyway.

I'm new to the Forza franchise and started with the Ultimate Edition so I can't comment on how the standard version is but from reading others reviews, I feel the Ultimate edition is a really great deal right now for $40, especially when everyone else is asking $70 to start for any of the other top titles that have less content but more issues and more panhandling.
So far, if there has been any additional asking for cash in the Ultimate edition, I haven't noticed it yet. While its not for me, as long as I'm not forced to watch "Buy our Monopoly money with your real money ads", or can easily bypass it, I can live with it being there.

All in all, I'd give it an 8 of 10. My wheel likes to startup in reverse on this game lately and I can't find a way to reverse it in the settings (Terrible GUI BTW). I'm not sure what this is but I'll let you know if I find out what's going on.

As an avid NFS player, this game was my foray into the sorta arcade/sim hybrid that is Forza. Lacking some of the customization that the NFS series has, Forza makes up with its sheer amount of cars. This is also one of, if not the, most beautiful games I have ever played. Cars feel good to drive (when you have them spec'd into grip and have stability turned on). All this said, there is plenty to do in this game, but it does get stale after awhile. I am 50 hours in, I have cleared all the actual races, but have barely touched the "story" (job) missions. I find them just... Kinda boring? I have certainly got my moneys worth from this game, but I couldn't recommend buying at full price. Also, unless you are just a completionist or a fan of a certain car, none of the dlc is worth buying aside from the map add-on.

Edit: So, while I do still love this game, and sunk even more hours into it trying to, finally, do the story/job missions as well as some of the dlc, it has come to my attention that there is a glitch where you will sometimes not get your seasonal rewards for hitting certain percentiles. This has been a glitch for some time, and with Motorsport just releasing a little while ago, not counting Horizon 5, I doubt it will ever be fixed. This realization does negatively effect my outlook on Horizon 4, and with nothing left to do but to drive around in my collection of, albeit, cool cars, with the seasonal grind being rendered potentially pointless, I believe I have no other choice than to finally close the door on this great game.

What can I say about a previous Forza game like this?

Well, for me, it's a good game. Even if I discover some of the cars that were absent in Horizon 5, I decide to make discoveries on a legacy game. I probably don't know what else to think, as Horizon 4 is outdated since that one last update when they added the VUHL. 

Its seasons are very well-defined for the atmosphere visuals, I think Winter is the most obvious change in the environment. And the game's map is decent enough. Even if we think FH5 gets a bigger map, it's probably not that big enough tbh. After roaming around for a long time, the map feels small already. XD

Therefore, I believe that FH4 and FH5 are equal to me. I eventually trust a game that has a lot of cars to drive, but I guess the devs would mind adding some cars from THIS to FH5 in later updates. It always happens, one way or another.

I've played at least 100 hours of this on Xbox and the MS Store version, re bought it on Steam so I could play on my Steam Deck. Easily of if not the best racing games of all time! The car selection is great, more would always be better (no DeLorean!?) but plenty to pick from within reason. The dynamic weather and terrain variety keep the game interesting and change the racing dynamics enough to keep the game engaging for hours, Performance on the Deck is good, I run the game at native resolution with medium dynamic dynamic render quality and lock the fps to 30 so there's virtually not dips. The game rarely has bugs or glitches and runs on most modern systems with ease. Highly recommended for any racing fan!

After playing 300 hours in this game, I felt compelled to share my thoughts. Firstly, the game boasts exceptional gameplay and graphics, and its optimization is top-notch. However, the music left much to be desired, prompting me to play the game exclusively with TimeLess Fm.

Having purchased nearly every DLC, I can confidently say that each one is worth the bought, except for one—Lego Speed Champions. Despite my initial optimism upon buying it, this DLC turned out to be disappointingly dull. I'm an avid fan of Lego games, as evident in my library, but this particular DLC fell short. It started promisingly but quickly became monotonous. In fact, I resorted to play it with YouTube videos to stave off boredom. The map design is lackluster, reminiscent of last-minute homework hastily completed.

The game is a visually stunning arcade racing that boasts a charming atmosphere and a diverse collection of beautifully modeled cars. The unskippable cutscenes, while immersive, unfortunately contribute to the bitter aftertaste of the game.

The allure of detailed maps comes at an additional cost of €3.99, creating a sense of nickel-and-diming for what should be standard features. Moreover, the incessant in-game ads and the attempt to entice players into purchasing DLC content during loading screens and map views taint the overall experience.

While the core gameplay delivers on the promise of a nice arcade racing experience, the monetization strategy leaves players with a feeling of greed overshadowing the initially enjoyable aspects. Despite its potential, it falls victim to a sad realization of prioritizing profit over player satisfaction.

[b]Forza Horizon 4 - The Pinnacle of Open-World Racing[/b]

Rating: ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

"Forza Horizon 4" is nothing short of a masterpiece in the racing game genre, setting the gold standard for open-world racing experiences. Developed by Playground Games and published by Microsoft Studios, this game is a breathtaking journey through the stunning landscapes of Great Britain, seamlessly blending realistic driving mechanics with an unparalleled sense of freedom and exploration.

The visual spectacle of "Forza Horizon 4" is nothing short of breathtaking. The changing seasons dynamically transform the world, from the vibrant blossoms of spring to the snowy wonderland of winter, creating a living, breathing environment that constantly keeps players on their toes. The attention to detail in the meticulously crafted world, complemented by stunning weather effects and day-night cycles, elevates the game into a visual marvel.

Driving enthusiasts will find themselves in awe of the meticulously designed roster of over 700 cars, each meticulously recreated with jaw-dropping attention to detail. The handling, whether you're behind the wheel of a high-performance hypercar or a vintage classic, is nothing short of sublime, striking a perfect balance between realism and accessibility for players of all skill levels.

The open-world design of the game is a triumph. The map is a playground of possibilities, encouraging exploration with hidden races, challenges, and stunning vistas waiting to be discovered. The seamless integration of the online shared world adds an extra layer of excitement, turning every drive into an opportunity for spontaneous competition or cooperation with other players.

The progression system is both engaging and rewarding, offering a diverse range of events and activities to keep players hooked for hours on end. The Festival atmosphere, complete with a vibrant music selection and an energetic atmosphere, adds a layer of immersion that enhances the overall experience.

The inclusion of the Route Creator tool allows players to design their own races, adding a creative element that extends the game's longevity and community engagement. The level of customization, both in terms of vehicles and character cosmetics, gives players a sense of ownership and personalization.

In conclusion, "Forza Horizon 4" is the epitome of open-world racing perfection. With its breathtaking visuals, diverse and extensive car roster, seamless online integration, and engaging gameplay, it sets the bar high for the racing genre. Whether you're a casual gamer or a hardcore racing enthusiast, "Forza Horizon 4" is an absolute must-play that showcases the pinnacle of what the gaming industry can achieve in the realm of virtual automotive experiences. Strap in, rev your engines, and get ready for an unforgettable ride.

My favorite racing game.
Buuuuuut the Steam version has a little problem that can occur when you buy the game. Online features might not work at all. And this is very important, because people do interesting challenges and custom trials and tunes of you car that give you a better experience and make cars drive better.

Soooo... I did a Teredo fix and other stuff, but nothing worked for me. I have FH4 on Game Pass, so I decided to check whether it would work there and... EVERYTHING WORKS (with no Firewall)! It's interesting, because FH5 works like magic on the same Steam version with all online features.

So here is the best Drive Settings that I've found:
- Drivatar Difficulty: Pro or less
- Braking: ABS On
- Steering: Simulation
- Traction Control: Off
- Stability Control: Off
- Shifting: Automatic
- Driving Line: Breaking Only
- Damage and Tire Wear: Cosmetic
- Rewind: On

Enjoy!

Lots of cars, the game is freeroam, awesome soundtrack, just plain awesome. As a quick introduction to the game, Forza Motorsport is the original series of Forza games. The Motorsport series is based around closed circuit racing ie: racing at a race track. Forza Motorsport is essentially Xbox/Microsoft's equivalent to Playstation/Sony's sim racer, the Gran Turismo series. The big difference is, Forza then made the Horizon series. Horizon is open world and simcade, this to me is a major plus. Gran Turismo currently as far as I'm aware, does not have an open world experience like this.

The general premise of Horizon is that there is a festival called the Horizon Festival that is set in some part of the world, to celebrate car culture. Horizon 4 takes place in a fictionalized UK, borrowing some real world locations/landmarks, and just mashing it all into one island.

The biggest plus with Horizon 4 is that it has all proper 4 seasons unlike you weirdos who live near the equator and don't experience snowy winters. Unlike Horizon 5 which takes place in Mexico, Horizon 4 has summer which is what you'd expect from summer, spring which is nice green scenery with loads of rain (typical UK?), autumn which is more rain, less green, more yellow and leaves, and finally...winter. Actual snow. Something that I never thought of as rare because I live in Canada, but to some of you who live in parts of the world with no snow, well....welcome to actual winter. Sadly it is the least active season because apparently all of you are scared of a little bit of snow, but this is currently the only Horizon game with all four seasons. Winter in Horizon 5 is NOT winter. If there is no snow, it is not winter. Simple. Sorry, not sorry. Every week is a season change, with that comes new (at this point its recycled) content. If only winter lasted for 7 days...unlike the miserable Canadian winters.

Overall the gameplay is fine, you can tune the difficulty to your liking against the Drivatars (AI racers using player names) which only affects how much money you earn so you don't always have to feel frustrated with Unbeatable Drivatars especially since the AI is notorious for defying physics despite driving lesser or seemingly equivalent cars than yours. My favourite is online. When in freeroam online, all players are ghosted, this way you can't be trolled while freeroaming (or if you're AFK) unless you convoy up with friends or invite people to it. However that only applies to Freeroam or Forzathon Lives. Collision is turned on when you actually do races and events or as mentioned above with a convoy.

I mentioned Forzathon Live, what is that? Honestly one of my favourite things in this game. Every day, every hour, there is a Forzathon Live, every 50 minutes, a giant pink circle is placed on the map, you and all the people who want to participate, drive to the circle, after a 10 minute timer (the game notifies you at the 5-6min mark and another notification for two minutes after it starts), Forzathon Live begins, you and all the players now drive to an area, and as a team, complete a common goal. For example, try and get a total speed of 10,000mph. How does this work? Well, there is a speed camera here, drive by it as fast as you can, you and all the participants need to do this until you reach 10,000mph. It sounds tough at first but with enough people and the right cars and strategy, its easy and fun. Meet new people, see cool cars, have fun driving in a non-competitive environment just doing car stuff. You do three rounds of this, and when you finish, you all get Forzathon points. 10, 20, 30 depending on how many rounds you manage to complete with the team, you get 20, 40, or 60 points if you have a specific house or VIP (which gives this house to you for free). These points can be used to buy rare cars in the Forzathon shop amongst other things. Always fun to do, non-competitive so you don't need to deal with sweaty tryhards, just have fun with the team, then once its over (either you guys completed it or you failed, no big deal either way) you all disperse and you can resume with whatever you were doing before.

Overall this is a great game, yes there are known issues with the game like not being able to get 100% seasonal completion amongst other things unfortunately, no game is perfect, but compared to Horizon 5, this game is still very good. Remember, Horizon 5 takes place in Mexico, the winter in that game? What winter? There is no snow on most of the map. Also the car list is slightly different, some cars in this game might not be in FH5 so this is important to note. Overall I would say its a solid 8.5/10 for me. I don't feel like writing anymore since I normally write long ass reviews anyways. If you're wondering which edition to buy, personally I recommend Ultimate, it includes ALMOST all DLCs. The only things you miss are the Hot Wheels car pack (you need it in order to buy those cars in-game, but they can be driven in custom made challenge cards), Treasure Map (unlocks all map stuff, not really important), and I think the Mitsubishi pack which is free. There is also two additional Free DLCs but they're hard to find unfortunately (check or ask in Steam discussions). Either way I would recommend Ultimate for all the DLCs as you CAN'T buy the DLC cars from the Autoshow, and apparently not even the auction house unless you own said DLCs.

Final Note: Since the licensing for some of the cars in this game are almost expired, unfortunately this game will be delisted from Steam at some point, when, I don't know as its still unconfirmed and its also the first Forza game on Steam. This could be your last chance to experience Horizon 4 and what it has to offer before its gone and you only have Horizon 5 which won't have a true winter experience amongst other things that Horizon 4 has, so if you see it on sale, grab Ultimate Edition if you can.

One of the [i]very, [/i][b][i]VERY[/i][/b], few racing games that gets us old racing games fans want to drive fast to Pop-Punk/Rock music (though [i]some[/i] of the songs are still... [i]questionable[/i])


[h1]Performance and Optimization[/h1]
FH4 also has the absolute [b][i]best [/i][/b]optimization I have ever seen in a game. With my mid tier PC on a 5400RPM External HDD, I was very surprised to see I was running at a steady 60fps on 4k with most graphic settings turned to ultra. It's absolute wizardry what Playground Games did here.
(ᶦᶠ ʸᵒᵘ ʷᵃⁿᵗ ᵗᵒ ˢᵉᵉ ᵐʸ ᵃᶜᵗᵘᵃˡ ˢᵖᵉᶜˢ ᵒᶠ ᵐʸ ᶜᵒᵐᵖᵘᵗᵉʳ ᵗᵒ ᶜᵒᵐᵖᵃʳᵉ ᵗᵒ ʸᵒᵘʳˢ, ʸᵒᵘ ᶜᵃⁿ ᶠᶦⁿᵈ ᶦᵗ ᵘⁿᵈᵉʳ ᵐʸ ᵇᶦᵒ ᵃᵗ ᵗʰᵉ ᵇᵒᵗᵗᵒᵐ)


[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The vehicles feel absolutely amazing. They're not super arcade-like and it feels like you're [i]actually[/i] driving a car that has weight to it. Customization of a car's parts even affects the car's performance which is [b]brilliant[/b] and an absolutely underrated feature.


There's an absolute [b][i]colossal[/i][/b] list of cars as well from [i]so[/i] many different manufacturers. The vehicle catalogue isn't [i]just[/i] your standard list of manufacturers that typically come with these Racing Games but includes many makes that I didn't even know existed. The [b][i]only[/i] problem[/b] that comes with such a big catalogue of cars is... looking through your garage can become overwhelming and you can easily lose, or forget, what car is for what type of content... The amount of times I've accidentally brought my drift car into a street race is ridiculous.




[h1]General Complaints[/h1]
Some of my [i]only[/i] complaints I have with this game is;
[list]
[*]Multiplayer (more specifically Online Adventure races) tend to break occasionally with a seemingly infinite loading screen. (Upwards of 7 minutes loading the next race)
[*]Character Customization is limited by an RNG Wheelspin for [i]almost[/i] all items. (ᴺᵒᵗᶦⁿᵍ: ᵂʰᵉᵉˡ ˢᵖᶦⁿˢ ᵃʳᵉ ᶠʳᵉᵉ ᵃⁿᵈ ᵉᵃʳⁿᵃᵇˡᵉ ʷᶦᵗʰ ᶦⁿ⁻ᵍᵃᵐᵉ ᶜᵘʳʳᵉⁿᶜʸ. ᵀʰᵉʳᵉ ᵃʳᵉ ᵃᵇˢᵒˡᵘᵗᵉˡʸ [b]ⁿᵒ[/b] [b]ᵐᶦᶜʳᵒᵗʳᵃⁿˢᵃᶜᵗᶦᵒⁿ[/b] ᶦⁿ ᵗʰᵉ ᵍᵃᵐᵉ)
[*]Some features are definitely geared towards kids with [i]very[/i] awkward-looking Fortnite Dances and [b][i]WAY[/i][/b] overly censored song lyrics.
[/list]


[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
After coming from The Crew 2, and being disappointed by Need For Speed's direction lately, I was absolutely amazed by this game's gameplay and I [i]absolutely[/i] recommend this game if you're a fan of racing games, especially if you've been playing open-world racing games for a while. [b][i]HOWEVER[/i][/b] buy this game on a sale. With Forza Horizon 5 being released with upgraded graphics and some more optimized gameplay features, this [b][i]isn't[/i][/b] worth the listed price of $60* for the base game anymore, [i]especially[/i] when it [b]reliably goes on sale[/b] every few months for $19.79* (though I would [b][i]definitely[/i][/b] recommend the Expansion Packs as well that come in the Ultimate Edition. UD has the same sale pattern and goes on sale for $34.99*).


I will also note, I've seen many players state they have problems with the steam version of this game. Personally, I've not run into any issues so far with crashing or not launching in my 100 hours of gameplay in my 2½ years of owning and playing this. Just be warned, it seems to be a hit or miss with [i]some[/i] people on being able to run this out-of-the-box.

Forza Horizon 4 is a Masterpiece

Forza Horizon 4 has undeniably claimed its spot on my top ten games list, and it's not hard to see why. This game is a racing masterpiece that combines stunning visuals, a vast open-world playground, and an unrivaled attention to detail that sets it apart from the competition.

Let's start with the visuals - they're nothing short of breathtaking. The dynamic weather system and the changing seasons add a level of realism that I've never experienced in a racing game before. The way the autumn leaves fall or the winter snow blankets the landscape is not only visually stunning but also affects the gameplay, making each race a unique and immersive experience.

The open-world design of Forza Horizon 4 is a true highlight. The map is a seamless blend of picturesque landscapes, from the city streets of Edinburgh to the scenic countryside of the Lake District. The diversity in terrain keeps the gameplay fresh and exciting, and there's always a new route or hidden spot to discover. The attention to detail in recreating a condensed, yet authentic, representation of Great Britain is commendable.

One of the aspects that truly sets Forza Horizon 4 apart is the car lineup. The roster is diverse, ranging from classic vintage cars to cutting-edge supercars, and everything in between. The level of customization available is staggering, allowing you to personalize every aspect of your ride to match your style. The sheer number of cars and the attention to detail in their design and handling make the racing experience incredibly immersive.

The gameplay is accessible to all skill levels, thanks to the various difficulty settings and assists. Whether you're a casual player looking for a relaxing drive through the countryside or a hardcore racer seeking a challenging competition, Forza Horizon 4 caters to everyone. The integration of a shared open-world with real players seamlessly adds an extra layer of excitement to races, creating a living, breathing online community.

The soundtrack deserves a special mention. The selection of music is eclectic, fitting various moods and creating an immersive atmosphere. The attention to detail in synchronizing the soundtrack with the dynamic weather and time of day adds an extra layer of enjoyment to the overall experience.

In conclusion, Forza Horizon 4 has exceeded my expectations in every aspect. It's a game that not only looks and feels amazing but also offers an unparalleled level of freedom and enjoyment. Playground Games has created a racing paradise that continues to captivate and entertain, earning its well-deserved spot on my top ten games list. If you have even the slightest interest in racing games, do yourself a favor and give Forza Horizon 4 a try – you won't be disappointed!

This is literally a gacha game but with cars.

I can safely say this game absolutely rocks. As somebody that generally despises Microsoft, this game studio is probably the best thing they have. Nowhere else can you have so much fun driving a retro Ferrari through fields and forests. I must have killed hundreds in head on crashes, and it's possible my real life driving habits have been affected, but overall the game is worth every penny. The best of the genre by a mile, and it's starting to replace boring sims with bad progression like GT7 for me personally. 

Graphics still looks fantastic on Extreme with a good PC, but they also run really well and there are no major issues outside the odd crash that rarely happens. 4K native looks really good, and the only slight drawback is some thankfully slight LOD pop-in here and there, as well cascading water reflections, but they are relatively minor all things considered.

Loads of stuff to do. Online was busy and functioning for me. No issues there. I highly recommend the Ultimate edition on sale. For around 35 bucks it sets you up like a king and from there it's all fun and games. Britain has been recreated quite well, and the four dynamic seasons are sorely missed from Forza 5. This is a top racing game. Timeless fun.

Forza Horizon 4 delivers an unparalleled racing experience that transcends the boundaries of the virtual realm. As a passionate racing enthusiast, I can confidently say that this game has set a new standard for open-world racing games, combining breathtaking visuals, an extensive car roster, and an immersive environment that keeps players hooked from start to finish.

The first thing that struck me was the sheer beauty of Forza Horizon 4's meticulously crafted world. Set in a stunning rendition of Great Britain, the changing seasons add a dynamic element to the gameplay. From the vibrant colors of spring to the icy landscapes of winter, each season not only alters the visual appeal but also transforms the driving dynamics, ensuring a fresh and exciting experience with every race.

The attention to detail in the cars is nothing short of extraordinary. With an extensive roster of over 450 meticulously recreated vehicles, from classic sports cars to modern hypercars, each one handles with precision, offering a unique driving experience. The level of realism is staggering, capturing the nuances of each vehicle's performance and making the joy of racing even more exhilarating.

Forza Horizon 4's open-world concept is a triumph in game design. The sprawling map is filled with diverse landscapes, including quaint villages, bustling cities, and challenging off-road terrains. The freedom to explore this vast environment creates a sense of adventure, and the seamless transition between solo and online play ensures a seamless and enjoyable multiplayer experience.

The game's progression system strikes a perfect balance between accessibility and depth. Whether you're a casual gamer or a hardcore racing enthusiast, Forza Horizon 4 caters to all skill levels. The Horizon Festival, the game's central hub, serves as a social space where players can engage in races, challenges, and events, fostering a sense of community among virtual racers.

The soundtrack deserves special mention, featuring an eclectic mix of music that complements the game's energetic atmosphere. From pulse-pounding electronic beats to classic rock anthems, the soundtrack enhances the overall immersive experience and adds an extra layer of enjoyment to the game.

In conclusion, Forza Horizon 4 is a masterpiece in the racing genre, offering an unparalleled combination of stunning visuals, realistic driving mechanics, and an expansive open-world environment. Whether you're a casual gamer looking for a thrilling joyride or a dedicated racing enthusiast seeking a comprehensive experience, Forza Horizon 4 delivers on all fronts. It's not just a game; it's a celebration of the art and joy of racing. Buckle up and get ready for the ride of a lifetime!

Forza Horizon 4, the latest installment in the acclaimed racing franchise, sets a new standard for realism and variety in the world of virtual driving. Developed by Playground Games and published by Microsoft Studios, this game delivers an unparalleled experience with its authentic car controls and a diverse array of vehicles and tracks that cater to every racing enthusiast's desires.

Forza Horizon 4 shines brightest in its dedication to delivering realistic car controls. The attention to detail is evident from the moment you take control of your first vehicle. The responsiveness of the cars, the way they handle various terrains, and the nuanced physics make for an incredibly immersive experience. Whether you're drifting through the tight corners of a city circuit or tearing through the open countryside, each vehicle feels distinct, providing a true-to-life driving sensation.

The game's realistic weather effects further elevate the driving experience. Rain-slicked roads affect traction, and the changing seasons introduce dynamic challenges, such as snow-covered surfaces that demand adjustments to your driving style. Forza Horizon 4's commitment to authenticity sets it apart, making every race feel like a genuine test of skill.

One of the standout features of Forza Horizon 4 is the extensive roster of cars spanning different categories. From sleek sports cars and powerful muscle machines to rugged off-road vehicles, there's a car for every taste and preference. The inclusion of classic and modern cars from various manufacturers adds depth to the game, ensuring players can find their dream ride.

While the variety is impressive, some players may find that certain categories receive more attention than others. However, regular updates and expansions continue to introduce new vehicles, ensuring the game remains fresh and engaging for the long term.

Forza Horizon 4 doesn't just limit itself to standard racetracks. Instead, it offers a diverse range of environments and terrains, providing players with a true adventure in every race. Dirt racing, off-roading, drag racing – the game caters to all tastes, offering tracks that challenge your skills in different ways.

The meticulously crafted landscapes, including a dynamic day-night cycle and the breathtaking beauty of changing seasons, contribute to an immersive racing experience. The attention to detail in track design ensures that each race feels unique, whether you're tearing through the streets of a historic city or navigating the treacherous paths of a cross-country circuit.

Forza Horizon 4 sets the bar high for racing games with its realistic car controls, diverse car categories, and thrilling tracks across various terrains. While no game is without its minor imperfections, the overall experience is nothing short of exhilarating. Whether you're a casual racing fan or a dedicated enthusiast, Forza Horizon 4 offers an unforgettable journey into the world of high-speed, high-stakes racing. Buckle up and get ready for a ride like no other.

It is famous for playing less racing games. After experiencing most of the content that can unlock achievements, I have organized some notes for non professionals, for reference only. First of all, the conclusion is that the game is worth playing, but it is not recommended to blindly follow the trend.
The absolute value of game quality is 4 stars, and the deduction of 1 star is due to poor online content experience and some achievements that are too outrageous. Check "not recommended" because the Steam version has the problem of cutting corners and there are too many useless fake likes and bad reviews!
Advantages: First rate image quality, a masterpiece in photography. Excellent music with numerous divine songs. Optimization is very good. There are many details, dust, soil, and snow can splash on the car, and their distribution in different areas will also change over time. Rainbows appear after rain, snowmen build on the roadside in winter, and fireworks are set off at night in the main camp. The competition part was very enjoyable, especially as I watched myself being bullied from the beginning to gradually challenging higher-level AI and leaving them behind. At the same time, I also had leisure to enjoy the scenery. If I could come across beautiful songs, it would be even more wonderful. The day and night weather season system is complete, and there is no shortage of drifting, speed measurement, and long jump that racing games should have. There is also a variety of multi-purpose vehicles for multi terrain competitions. Wealth Island DLC is very exciting. Lego DLC God of the Gods.
Disadvantages, to be honest, unfortunately, the biggest drawback is that I found myself not enjoying the racing theme and many of its fixed gameplay. I came to play this game from Ubisoft Extreme Country's hundreds of hour retreat pit. I thought I would like it because it's all about racing, but the problem is here. I only enjoy playing the content of racing races, and I can't enjoy the rest of the racing themed content. Horizon 4 is a game that completely revolves around racing, with many gameplay and content that are very addictive. Racing is only a small part of it, and it is even different from the Need for Speed series that I had a great time playing with. Due to the elements of police and bandit confrontation, Need for Speed is still a racing part, which accounts for a considerable proportion compared to other content. On the contrary, Horizon 4 weakens the proportion of racing content, I have done too much tedious numerical challenge content, and the focus is clearly more on the online multiplayer part and high-quality model performance. Coincidentally, these are not the contents that I care about. In fact, by the time I played the game for half an hour, I had already felt bored and felt that the content was highly repetitive and scattered. Unfortunately, I couldn't get a refund for the key I bought. I thought I could play it as an achievement driven game, but in the end, the difficulty of my achievements successfully persuaded me to quit
Also, because I came from an extreme country, I would unconsciously compare myself during the gameplay. I often feel that there is no special design in Extreme Land, and playing with Horizon has become an advantage. Of course, if you play it yourself, there may not be such a gap. I didn't mean to use Extreme Land to step on the horizon, but I found that one of these games focuses more on racing, while the other revolves entirely around racing themes. Writing them down in detail in the following text may help many people like me figure out what kind of game they need, so that they don't realize it's not suitable for them after playing. Another thing is that many of the functional designs of Horizon may be constrained by the times, resulting in a less enjoyable experience than subsequent works. I will also compile these. Just to emphasize, although the following text is quite lengthy, there are no drawbacks to the game that would make it completely impossible to play. Overall, I still recommend the game (worth playing).

TL:DR - Buy on a DEEP discount because the base game is pretty bare unless you want to shell out big bucks on DLC.

Overall, this game is fun with a lot of different free-roam mechanics to keep you busy.  The cars look pretty good, but not exactly Gran Turismo level of eye-popping realism (car  interiors look like they textures havent rendered). There are lots  of vehicles and tuning options and plenty of races, stunts, and off-beat levels like the Top Gear missions. 

Where this game falters is the endless stream of microtransactions they shove in your face. In between seasons there is a non-skippable video about all the DLC you are missing out on.  I've seen the video twice in 10 gameplay hours. 
The vehicle roster looks large from the outset, but at least half of the cars are locked behind pay-walls. Additionally there are DLC items on the maps at all times trying to lure you into paying another $20--$40 on top of the regular game to enjoy legoland. 

This is my first Forza game, but I dont think I will come back to the franchise anytime soon.  The microtransactions do not add to the game, they ARE the game. I dont even feel comfortable letting my kids play it since the Mtx comes up so often I'm sure they will buy uselsss add-ons by accident. 

Shame on you Microsoft, and all gaming companies with predatory practices, we pay for a full game, so RELEASE A FULL GAME.
