Forza Horizon 4, developed by Playground Games and published by Microsoft Studios, stands as a shining example of excellence in the world of racing games. Released in 2018, the game has captivated players with its stunning visuals, realistic driving mechanics, expansive open-world environment, and an array of vehicles that span the automotive spectrum. In this essay, we will delve into the various aspects that make Forza Horizon 4 a standout title and why it has earned its reputation as one of the finest racing games of its time.

Visual Marvel:

One of the first things that strike players when they launch Forza Horizon 4 is its breathtaking visuals. The game is a visual marvel, boasting a meticulously crafted open-world environment set in the picturesque landscapes of Great Britain. The attention to detail is unparalleled, with each season – spring, summer, autumn, and winter – bringing a distinct and immersive aesthetic to the game. Whether it's the vibrant colors of autumn leaves or the serene beauty of a snowy winter landscape, Forza Horizon 4's graphics are a testament to the capabilities of modern gaming technology.

The realism extends beyond the environment to the cars themselves. Each vehicle is meticulously rendered, showcasing the intricate details of their design, from the gleaming curves of a luxury sports car to the rugged exterior of an off-road vehicle. The dynamic weather system further enhances the visual experience, as raindrops bead on windshields and snow accumulates on the road, affecting the handling of vehicles. The visual fidelity of Forza Horizon 4 is not just eye candy; it plays a crucial role in immersing players in the virtual racing experience.

Realistic Driving Mechanics:

Forza Horizon 4 strikes a delicate balance between realism and accessibility in its driving mechanics. The game offers a diverse range of cars, each with its own unique handling characteristics that reflect their real-world counterparts. Whether you're tearing through the countryside in a high-performance supercar or navigating tight city streets in a compact hatchback, the responsiveness of the controls and the physics engine make every vehicle feel distinct and authentic.

The realism is enhanced by the game's attention to detail in terms of tire grip, suspension dynamics, and vehicle weight. Players can feel the difference between driving on wet and dry surfaces, and the changing weather conditions add an extra layer of challenge to the driving experience. Despite the authenticity, Forza Horizon 4 remains accessible to players of varying skill levels, thanks to adjustable difficulty settings and a range of driving assists that can be tailored to individual preferences.

Open-World Exploration:

Forza Horizon 4's open-world environment is a sprawling playground for automotive enthusiasts. The map, a condensed but faithful representation of Great Britain, offers a diverse range of terrains, from the bustling streets of Edinburgh to the winding roads of the Lake District. The seamless transition between seasons not only affects the visual landscape but also transforms the driving experience. Lakes freeze over in winter, opening up new routes, and spring brings vibrant foliage that enhances the overall aesthetics of the game.

The open-world design encourages exploration, with hidden barn finds, stunt jumps, and races scattered across the map. The sense of freedom is amplified by the absence of traditional race tracks, allowing players to chart their own course through the picturesque landscapes. The ability to seamlessly transition between solo and online play further adds to the dynamic nature of Forza Horizon 4, as players can engage in cooperative races, competitive events, or simply cruise around the open world with friends.

A Plethora of Vehicles:

Forza Horizon 4 boasts an extensive and diverse roster of over 700 vehicles, ranging from classic cars to modern hypercars and everything in between. The meticulous attention to detail extends to each vehicle's sound design, ensuring that the roar of a V8 engine or the whine of an electric motor is faithfully reproduced. The cars are not merely cosmetic additions; they are integral to the gameplay experience, each offering a unique driving feel that caters to different preferences.

The game's deep customization options allow players to personalize their vehicles, from performance upgrades to cosmetic modifications. Whether you're a gearhead fine-tuning every aspect of your car's performance or a casual player looking to express your creativity through unique paint jobs and decals, Forza Horizon 4 accommodates a wide spectrum of player preferences.

Dynamic Multiplayer Experience:

Forza Horizon 4 seamlessly integrates multiplayer elements into its open-world design. The game features a shared online world where players from around the globe can coexist, participate in events, and engage in spontaneous races. The dynamic nature of the open world ensures that each session feels alive, with real-time events and challenges that can be tackled solo or cooperatively with other players.

The competitive aspect of Forza Horizon 4 is realized through its ranked multiplayer modes, where players can test their skills against others in a variety of race types. The ranking system ensures a fair matchmaking experience, pitting players of similar skill levels against each other for a competitive and satisfying multiplayer experience.

Conclusion:

Forza Horizon 4 is not merely a racing game; it is a symphony of sight, sound, and sensation that combines to create an unparalleled gaming experience. Its stunning visuals, realistic driving mechanics, expansive open-world environment, diverse vehicle roster, and dynamic multiplayer features collectively contribute to its status as a masterpiece in the racing game genre. As players immerse themselves in the virtual world of Forza Horizon 4, they are not just racing cars; they are experiencing the culmination of gaming technology, attention to detail, and a deep passion for the art of automotive excitement.

Forza Horizon 4 is a good car driving game to suggest with various singleplayer contents to spend time alone. Many contents of the game makes you to mostly enjoy discovering the world and running races as co-op instead of competitive racing against other players, which makes this game very friendly to beginners who are simply want to try driving games. You can enjoy beautiful open world that has changing season/weather which allows you to have different experience every race or week. Soundtracks for the game are mostly very good too. There is no doubt about recommending this game to anyone willing to give a try, but here are some concerning things about the game if you are hesitating:

Although this game is very chill driving game to enjoy as a beginner, the game is definitely not meeting players' expectation who would want to see less stressful racing simulation that happens in anywhere in the world. While the game feels a bit harder than casual racing, ultimately it feels very close to arcade rather than open world sim racing, which it seems like making the game to be in weird position to target neither groups of players and even possibly be somewhat challenging.

Also, forced weekly season can heavily affect your singleplayer experience. Usually the season doesn't bother you too much while you simply try to participate event races where it lets you to choose own cars with proper tuning, and where you can change conditions as well. But when it comes to clearing many chapter missions that asks you come into finishing point by very sharp time, it gets nearly impossible if you can't take any shortcuts yet the weather is winter, while forcing you to use cars that are not prepared for such weather conditions. Because you can't change weather other than temporary custom racing event, it gets really annoying rather than feeling immersive driving experience.

The only reason why I would not pay for full price is because the game has so many minor bugs that players have to figure out and manually handle how to deal with them. This game has been out for about 5 years, and yet you still don't see the developers actively handling frequent issues that hinders your overall experience.

Just buy it..............

It only usually happens above 150mph, and it's a bug in the game. I fixed mine by installing on my m.2 SSD and it works brilliantly now. Forza Horizon 4, a gem for sure but it does have some blemishes:

- Micro-stuttering, crashing, no save game transfer from Xbox App and some steam achievements don't unlock after achieving them. I have over 300 Hours in this game via the game pass. What a shame.

- Corrupted my save game files. If you like the risk of starting over after dodgy updates then you're looking at the best game for that.

[Edit 3.0] After about a year of leaving the game alone and on acquisition of a GPU with 4GB of video memory I am able to enjoy this game again. No corruption of save game files thus far, less micro-stuttering and an overall nice experience. I had some trouble with the Xbox app [which is necessary if you want to play FH4 online] but after a re-install of the Xbox App via the Website [not Microsoft Store - it doesn't work via that] I was able to connect the game again after Signing Out and Signing back into my Xbox Account via the FH4 Start Menu before loading the game. Still no save game sync from Xbox App but seems to sync progress via Steam Cloud just fine. Still crashes occasionally when entering houses which is annoying.

>>>2023 Updated EDIT 4.0: Crashes, Crashes, Crashes. Especially when playing with friends online, the more friends you invite the more the game crashes. Impossible to get 100% game completion at this time, achievements don't pop up properly, the loading times for Online Adventures are atrocious[You wait FOREVER to Find A Session]. Not worth the hassle I'm afraid if you like playing online and you are OCD on completing the game.

+ But if you can get past all of the negatives this game is probably one of the best racing games I've ever played, and I've played many since I started playing racing games back in 1999.

+ Loads of content! Like, really this game will keep you busy for months.

+ Can be played comfortably solo but I highly recommend doing all of the online adventures, especially ranked, because you'll be gifted a ton of stuff once the season is over!

+ The rewards system and game pacing is excellent, I don't get bored easily with this game (except if I need to delete my save game files due to updates corrupting my profile)

+ So many cool cars and childhood faves including [SPOILER ALERT!!!!!] go see for yourself :) over 700 cars!!

+ If you have the hardware, this game looks GORGEOUS!!

+ Can be played comfortably with a computer keyboard

+ Multiplayer with friends is a lot of fun

+ Sounds are pretty good but not the best (GRID & DIRT still rule here), love the soundtrack but it can become pretty repetitive. (Especially when re-doing your career because of corrupted save games............)

+ Large maps and cool expansion packs.

[Overall] Despite the tons of annoying bugs - this game is absolutely fantastic. I love cars and to be able to drive a bunch of legendary cars and upgrade them beyond recognition is a real treat. The career mode is brilliant and entertaining, the online challenges are tough but fun and very rewarding, when they work.

My complaints:
There are some stupid gimmicks. For example this "Forzathon" and "Festival Playlist" crap. To someone who's new to the series and hasn't already grown accustomed to it, these things just clutter the UI.
The UI is... a thing. It makes sense, for the most part. My problem is with having to be at a hub somewhere on the map to do upgrade or buy cars. This can be annoying when I just got decimated in a race and need to adjust my car but I have to travel across the map to do so. I can't just upgrade my vehicle right there at the race.
Buying houses does not make sense. You can fast travel to the Horizon Festival for free. So what's the point in purchasing a 3 million dollar house?
By far my biggest complaint is with the NPC drivers, referred to "Drivatars" in-game. They are constantly getting in the way. The devs obviously noticed this because they provided a few places in Forza 5 where you can just test drive cars without crashing into NPCs. Unfortunately, this is absent in Forza 4 where all the roads are quite heavily populated with Drivatars you're expected to dodge. This makes is inextricably difficult to hit top speed in the fastest vehicles.
A slight complaint is with the mods themselves. Apparently, it's rather easy to get banned for using money tricks. Which is stupid. Even EA has accepted that people cheat code Sims to beyond the point of recognition. Get with the times.

Forza Horizon 4 is a stellar racing game that not only excels in delivering a thrilling and immersive gaming experience but also stands out for its incredible realism. The attention to detail in recreating the environment, the cars, and the overall physics of the game is nothing short of impressive.

One of the standout features is the game's stunning graphics and lifelike landscapes. The open-world environment, set in a beautifully rendered version of Great Britain, is breathtaking. The changing seasons not only add visual diversity but also impact the gameplay, making the world dynamic and engaging.

The realism extends to the car models and their handling. Each car is meticulously recreated, capturing every detail, from the sleek curves to the manufacturer's emblem. The attention to detail also extends to the interior of the cars, allowing players to experience a sense of immersion as they navigate through the game.

What truly sets Forza Horizon 4 apart is the authenticity of its car sounds. The engine roars, tire screeches, and gear shifts are so realistic that they contribute significantly to the overall immersive experience. Whether you're tearing through the countryside or racing through urban streets, the audio design makes you feel like you're right there in the driver's seat.

The game's realistic physics add to the challenge and excitement. Weather conditions affect the road grip, and each car responds differently, providing a nuanced driving experience. This attention to realism doesn't compromise the fun factor; instead, it enhances it.

Forza Horizon 4's commitment to realism, coupled with its diverse and expansive gameplay, makes it a standout racing game. Whether you're a car enthusiast or simply enjoy a well-crafted game, Forza Horizon 4 delivers an unparalleled experience that is as close to the real thing as it gets in the world of gaming.

I see why so many people prefer this over fh5 now after finally getting it. Just something about this game has a cozy vibe to it that hasn't been matched. The map is lovely so far, the car selection is varied, the soundtrack is top notch for my preferred stations, I can't complain. 

It's weird, fh5's map is beautiful in its own right but this just has some sort of magic to it, which is only enhanced by the seasons which i didn't originally like but I now love. Drifting on snowy roads feels so satisfying it's worth buying to experience that alone. I also prefer the feel of this game's physics, it feels just about perfect for what I want out of a racing game.

Sadly I don't see myself going back to fh5 anymore, but this will be my new racing home while we wait for 6. Fingers crossed for japan next!
Very solid-tastic game. What else can I say?

This is a fantastic game for a driving simulator.  I've always wanted to know what driving expensive cars would be like if my steering column snapped in half while driving on the moon.  Truly the pinnacle of physics and driving simulation.  Watch as the framerates running through your high-end GPU consistently drop to new and unexplored levels of choppiness.  --But hey, given that this game released 5-6 years ago, I understand why the graphics would be choppier than CyberPunk 2077.  It's quite understandable, especially from a small software startup like Microsoft.  Definitely worth $200 for the combined package of 4 and 5!

i spend more time trying to get this pos game to work then playing it   crashes on AMD and NVIDIA  cards  was working fine on my new lap top then NVIDIA updated and it started crashing so i put it on my desktop with AMD card and it wouldn't  let me go online in till i   re logged in and then  after i figured that out i played half a race  then it crashed so i wrote this review this is after i spent  days figuring out  why the sound was all messed up on Bluetooth wireless earbuds  because  u a have to turn off the  telephone feature on your ear buds because its 2023 and no one in Microsoft uses Bluetooth ear buds when test games  this is F**king crazy     only Microsoft  could get it so backwards

UPDATE 
************
OK ill admit this is one of my favorite  car games  but it really makes me work for it this game ran  flawlessly  on my new laptop i bought in October 2022   then recently forza announced that a gpu update  was available (march 2023) so i updated that is when my game started  freezing  so i preserve and   uninstalled  my gpu drivers  im running a i7  12th gen  with a RTX 3060  6 gig  after installing the newest  NVIDIA drivers and still getting the same freezing  i  went on the NVIDIA site to download older version of the drivers  ( google old NVIDIA drivers ) after trying several i found the studio drivers from  	October 18, 2022     version  	522.30   work and the freezing is gone now is it ideal no will i recommend  this game now  NO it has pis*ed me off  i shouldn't  have to  roll back my drivers  to play a triple A title but i still love  the game itself ...

Not an arcade style racer but enjoyable nonetheless, while it can be frustrating perfecting one's tunes, there are many player-created tunes available which get the job done. Experimenting with different cars and disciplines is time-consuming but enjoyable. The world is cozy and well thought out with the seasonal mechanic lending much diversity to each race. A major plus would be the fact that this game is SO well optimised and even the most potato PC (such as mine) can run the game at high settings without a single frame drop.

Really a lovely game, but please do dress warmly while playing it, as the effing game freezes 3-4 times / hour (and sometimes even more frequently) - hence the thumb down. Windows 10 and the latest nVidia drivers.

Edit after additional 33 hours: Seems much improved now - I don't know if it's a game patch or nVidia driver affair, but it stopped crashing for me.

[b]Forza Horizon 4 cruises into the racing genre, delivering a vibrant open-world experience that captures the thrill of speed and exploration.[/b]
[list]
[*]Stunning Visuals: The game's picturesque landscapes and detailed car models exhibit breathtaking visuals, setting a high bar for realism in racing games. (Pro)
[*]Dynamic Seasons: The rotating seasons feature adds depth to the gameplay, offering diverse driving conditions and an ever-evolving world. (Pro)
[*]Expansive Car Collection: With a vast array of cars to choose from, including iconic classics and modern supercars, the game caters to diverse automotive tastes. (Pro)
[*]Engaging Open World: The sprawling map of Great Britain provides ample opportunities for exploration, races, and discovering hidden treasures. (Pro)
[*]Accessibility and Fun: The game strikes a balance between accessibility for casual players and depth for racing enthusiasts, making it enjoyable for various skill levels. (Pro)
[*]Limited Storyline: While the game's emphasis on free exploration is commendable, some players might miss a more developed narrative or structured progression. (Con)
[*]Online Connectivity Issues: Occasional server issues or connectivity hiccups during online gameplay can disrupt the multiplayer experience. (Con)
[*]Limited Customization: Despite an extensive car roster, the customization options for vehicles may feel limited compared to other racing titles. (Con)
[/list]
[b][i]In summary, Forza Horizon 4 revs up as an outstanding open-world racing game, offering stunning visuals, dynamic seasons, and a vast car collection, making it a thrilling experience for racing aficionados. However, the game's lacking narrative depth, online connectivity hiccups, and limited customization options might slightly detract from the overall experience for some players. Nevertheless, its accessible gameplay and expansive world make it a worthwhile addition to any racing enthusiast's library.[/i][/b]

Liked: 
- The Setting (Great Britain); however Edinburgh is super watered down!
- Changing of Seasons
- Racing Mechanics
- Music
- Graphics/Performance

Disliked:
- Xbox App Integration Mandatory (popups are so annoying!)
- Set pieces (showcases) are beautiful but feel so scripted
- The open world driving to races - just let me race!
- Story is pretty much non-existent (and I'm a single player gamer)
- To get more than 7ish hours out of the game, you have to be racing or collecting for their own sake and not for story purposes

Score: 6.5/10 - Would recommend the game if you love racing (particularly off-road racing) and can get it on sale, or if you love open-world online racing. Otherwise I've enjoyed other racing games much more and similar non-racing games (Riders Republic) a lot more as well.

Look, this game is amazing in so many ways, but I cannot in good conscience recommend it considering that the devs have made it clear that they do not plan meaningfully continue support for the game.

There was nearly 6 months of a major crash bug affecting Nvidia users, and now we're more than half a year into a bug where players just don't get rewards they've earned from weekly/monthly seasonal/series challenges, specifically the Horizon Backstage Passes.

These are essentially coupons players can redeem for very rare cars, except for many months now players haven't been receiving them, meaning that if you're trying to complete your car collection you basically cannot, because many of the Backstage cars cannot realistically be obtained any other way and are never on the auction house.

The devs have clearly stated that they know about the bug but that they have "no plans" to fix it because they're too busy working on FH5 (which just got new microtransactions that have upset the playerbase).

I'll happily change my review if and when this gets fixed, but currently the game owes me literally about two *dozen* backstage passes.

AT A MINIMUM, they should just start giving the players a free backstage pass every week to compensate for the bug they refuse to fix.

Really fun game too play. Driving through the tight roads of the city is just stunning to watch. There is a large variety of cars to drive and you can get almost any car pretty quickly if you just play. Probably the best driving simulator I've played, but I do have a few gripes with it.

1. Microsoft account
2. The inability to skip seasons (winter) is lame. I'm depressed by winter IRL; I don't want it in my escapism.
3. The fact that you have to install "racing brakes" on every individual car to adjust brake pressure is outright dumb, especially since the default of all cars is "even a bit of brake is slamming the brakes".
4. Championships that make you buy a new car all the time. This wouldn't be so bad if it weren't for point 3.

So all in all it's great, and probably the best setting of the Horizon games thus far, but it should've been more user-friendly to those who don't want to drop 300 on a wheel and pedals

[h1]"Forza Horizon 4: The Ultimate Racing Playground"[/h1]


Forza Horizon 4 isn't just a game; it's a heart-pounding, eye-popping love letter to speed demons and car enthusiasts alike. Brace yourself for an open-world racing adventure that's nothing short of exhilarating.

The game's trump card? Dynamic seasons that don't just change the scenery but alter the entire racing experience. From icy winter drifts to sun-soaked summer sprints, every race feels like a new challenge, keeping you hooked and the adrenaline pumping.

And let's talk cars—Forza Horizon 4 boasts a jaw-dropping garage, featuring everything from vintage classics to futuristic speed demons. Each ride is a symphony of speed, with meticulously crafted details and engine roars that'll send shivers down your spine.

The shared world multiplayer is where the game truly revs its engine. Connect with players worldwide in a vibrant online community, where every race is a chance to prove your skills or team up for wild cooperative challenges.

Graphically, it's a feast for the eyes. The stunning visuals and seamless performance make every race an immersive joyride, even on a mid-range setup.

In the world of open-world racing, Forza Horizon 4 stands tall as the undisputed champion. It's not just a game; it's an addiction, a rush, and an experience that'll keep you coming back for more. Buckle up; this is one ride you don't want to miss. Forza Horizon 4: Where the road meets pure gaming bliss.

I bought the deluxe edition after the Steam release. I recommend taking it (especially on sale only for $30), because it contains many exclusive cars that perform well in their class. My impressions are amazing. It is very relaxing, will not let you get bored (many different races, network modes and more) and will not force you to farm on cars - they will "accumulate" in the garage themselves. I liked the physics - almost everything on the map is interactive; graphics and optimization at height; large car garage; change of seasons. There are also 2 DLC’s with original maps.

According to reviews, the edition in Steam is more buggy than in MS.
Very disappointed with the network mode with its bugs, 10-minute "fast" movement, departures from the network mode, issue that can’t connect to Xbox live servers... 

And if we talk about it.. why we need to connect our Steam account to Xbox account? Then what is the advantage of the fucking Steam version?

There is no simple chatting with others (because it’s olny 4 customized prepeared answers), no in-campaing team-racing (because it’s impossible to find just a 3-men race, I don’t know why). 

Game have a well music, but IT CAN’T BE fully turned off. It boring every time you have a race loading screen. The AI is bad, seriously, but only “drivatars”. NPC’s is also bad namely their animations and faces (it’s not a huge issue, it’s a racing game). From this we can understand that the game has a not-offensive kid friendly athmosphere and it is nasty.

In general offline game is pretty good, but online part not as good as we wanted. Devs not updating the game and don’t fixing this major issues they are engaged in disgusting FH5.

It's pretty, and not really fun. A plow through fields simulator. The events are scattered about the map, but it all seemed so random, I can't tell any real purpose to playing.

Today when I played I got unskippable ads for DLC, and this was when I realized the sound was too high, but it wouldn't let me escape to the settings. I just took my headphones off at that point.

And they still put the events for DLC you don't have on your map. Went to one, just a link to the marketplace when I got there. I guess I'll drive to some other icon on the map and hope it's available to me....

am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Forza Horizon 4 is an absolute blast! Cruising through the stunning British countryside is like a visual treat for your eyes. The changing seasons keep things interesting, making every drive a new adventure. I love the huge variety of cars – from flashy sports cars to rugged off-roaders, there's something for every mood. The game's attention to detail is top-notch, with realistic engine sounds and screeching tires that make you feel like you're really in the driver's seat. Exploring the open world at my own pace is a joy, and jumping into multiplayer races with friends is seamless fun. Forza Horizon 4 is a must-play for any racing game fan!

Forza Horizon 4 is my favourite Forza game. Here's why,

The game's graphics are a standout feature, showcasing the capabilities of modern gaming technology. The level of detail in the cars, the realistic weather effects, and the seamless transition between seasons contribute to a visually breathtaking experience. Whether you're racing through the rain-soaked streets of Edinburgh or drifting on the icy roads in winter, Forza Horizon 4 delivers a visually diverse and engaging racing environment.

The handling and physics of the cars are finely tuned, striking a balance between realism and accessibility. Each vehicle feels unique, and the wide range of cars, from sleek sports cars to off-road vehicles, caters to a variety of racing preferences.

The customization options in Forza Horizon 4 are extensive, allowing players to personalize their cars to an impressive degree. (Scarily impressive!)

Forza Horizon 4 stands as a pinnacle in the racing game genre. Its stunning visuals, realistic driving mechanics, extensive car customization, and seamless integration of multiplayer elements make it a must-play for both racing enthusiasts and casual gamers alike.

I recommend this game purely on it's open world driving and the fun spread of content.
But if you go beyond the developers idea of how the game should be played it really shows its flaws.
If you turn all of the assists off and play as realistically as possible, the game is much more fun to play with even greater rewards, but it completely breaks the AI. I've seen my own car get artificially slowed down and the AI get sped up far beyond their acceleration capabilities.
Even at the above average AI setting, which should be a completely reasonable difficulty, you have to drive dirty to finish 1st.
I can't even imagine playing this on the hardest difficulty, but at least the game is fun in one of tens of configurations.
Also, the forzathon and playlist series are a huge waste of time and prey upon gamers sense of FOMO.
It shows you years of updates and all of the stuff you've already missed out on, as well as push you to play challenges that are unfair and unfun.
If you want to play this game, you're better off doing it offline and just enjoying it at whatever difficulty you can tolerate.
It is still fun, so I still recommend it, but be wary of it.

Forza Horizon is just a fun game, one which I love playing. I recommend it for anyone who wants a game they can just load up and play. I love this game for what it is - an arcade racer which belt feeds you progression.

Whilst I yearn for those arcade racers such as Need for Speed underground 2 and Most wanted which have hard earned progression with cars which you keep for hours on end slowly developing before investing in a better car, they simply do not exist anymore.

I don't recommend this game for anyone who loves feeling a sense of accomplishment. Its very very easy, even with the difficulty set high. Its forgiving, the obstacles melt like butter and don't slow you down, there are no penalties really for mistakes unless you hit a really big tree or a house. The story-line progression is so fast that you almost feel like you want to slow it down or raise the progression points, the in-game seasons and race championship tiers fly by before you've even started to experience them properly. Race entry limitations are pretty much non existent and you gain cars and money so quickly that nursing a particular car is unnecessary - if you find your current car lacking you can either max its upgrades out before a race or just buy another car if the game hasnt already given you a better one, the money you gain right off the bat is more than you'll ever need and buying the car pass cuts out the middle man here, it literally fills your garage and wallet up right from the start.

For some these things might be boring, and if i didnt have half a dozen sensible racing games I would mind. But I dont, its fun!! ^^

The driving game I always wanted, with one major caveat which gives it a negative rating.

I played American Truck Simulator before, but it just focused on huge slow semi trucks, and I also played F1 2017 before, but it was just focused on the track and the track only. I wanted a game where I could just drive around a large map with a variety of sports cars and supercars, allowing for partial throttle/brake (controller needed) because nobody just floors it all the time when driving normally.

And that's what this game is. No story distracting myself from the gameplay. Racing events and challenges are there if I feel like it but almost never seem forced on you. Many difficulty options to choose from allowing for a nice casual race or a huge challenge.

BUT:  This game has unskippable video ads interrupting the gameplay. Yes, you heard me right. UNSKIPPABLE VIDEO ADS INTERRUPTING GAMEPLAY. This has only happened about 3 times so far, but rarely when you go into a loading screen, the game decides to BLAST a FULL-VOLUME ad for one of the expansion DLCs. This ad is unskippable and lasts TWO MINUTES. Completely unacceptable. Not buying any DLCs for this game (that I probably would've otherwise bought) out of spite. Shame on this singlehandedly bringing a 9/10 game to a 7/10 game. I cannot bring myself to recommend this game when this happens. F*** the publishers who thought the ads were a good idea.

Forza Horizon 5 doesn't do this. It also has much better sounds and a more varied map. Just get that game instead. Or go for a competitor, like BeamNG Drive if you like the sandbox experience with the realistic crashing, or Crew: Motorfest, or something else.

Other cons:
1. A bit too many DLCs for my liking. The major expansions are fine but there's many "car packs" and other crap that I shouldn't be getting locked out of my full-priced game.
2. No way to completely disable some sounds. I really don't need to have sound effects blasting my ears, especially with that stupid thunder loading screen.
3. Not the most stable game ever. The game has crashed quite a few times, but not enough to make the game unplayable by any means.

From my perspectove let me tell you about the absolute gem that is Forza Horizon 4. I've been burning rubber in virtual worlds for a while, but this game takes the cake for being an all-around stunner.

First off, the visuals – oh boy, they're mind-blowing. Playground Games nailed the British countryside, and it's not just eye candy. The seasons change, and it's not just for show; it actually messes with the way you tear up the roads. Winter is icy and tricky, while summer feels like your tires are glued to the asphalt. It's not just racing; it's an immersive experience.

Now, let's talk cars. The lineup is a car enthusiast's fantasy come true. From sleek supercars that make you feel like a millionaire to off-road beasts that can handle any terrain, they've got it all. And the handling feels just right – realistic but not so hardcore that you need a degree in engineering to enjoy it. It strikes that perfect balance.

What really sets this game apart is the open-world setup. You're not confined to tracks; you've got this massive map to explore. And the best part? You can do it with friends. Imagine cruising through the English countryside with your buddies, stumbling upon hidden challenges and races – it's like a road trip where the road never ends.

Customization is another ace up Forza Horizon 4's sleeve. You can tweak your ride to your heart's content, both in terms of looks and performance. I've spent hours in the garage fine-tuning my cars, making them truly mine. The level of detail is insane.

And don't get me started on the multiplayer. It's seamlessly integrated into the world. You can team up with friends for races or go head-to-head with random players. It adds a whole new layer of excitement and unpredictability.

In a nutshell, Forza Horizon 4 isn't just a game; it's an experience. It's like the developers sat down and asked, "How can we make the ultimate racing game?" and then actually pulled it off. Whether you're a casual gamer looking for a good time or a hardcore racer wanting a challenge, this game's got you covered. Buckle up, hit the gas, and get ready for the road trip of a lifetime. (When I was a child and the game came out I was never able to play it because I had nowhere to play it and now that I have the chance to play it, it is the best of the best, it is almost 2024 and you can only describe this game with one word INCREDIBLE.
Its 2023 but still works good as hell!

Maybe its because I played Forza 5 first, but this game is terrible for using a wheel and shifter. So if you are only playing on control or pc, then this map is stunning at points and really fun, but for a driving experience: FORZA 5 IS WORLD'S BETTER! Don't get me wrong, I've loved playing parts of this game, but Forza 5 just took all of the really annoying or bad parts of Forza 4 and made them better. Customizing cars is easier and better, using a steering wheel feels better, and the community is more alive. Good game for visuals and a different area of the world to drive in, but Forza 5 would be mine vote.

A once joyous and enjoyable moment has now turned into something youll remember for the rest of your life as a negative moment. This games release was actually kind of decent and this being the first forza game i played with only a keyboard and a budget pc i saved up for years to build. I was happy playing this but as forza horizon 5 released its almost they dropped what there doing and left. Over the months passed. Less and less content was released and turned into dlc's then little to no updates and mostly just event after event which got stale fast. Anytime me or me trying to convince my friends to play they would stop playing after 30 minutes because they were tired of the bugs, game crashes and unplayable and frankly i was too. The devs have almosty nearly abandoned this game and its no longer fun to play since instead of enjoying the race experience you get to enjoy an unstable game. I dont like this game anymore since its been left behind to rot away from what it once was.

 Anyone who is considering buying this in 2023 or later. Dont even bother buying it on sale.

Coud have been a great game if it does not always crash with no fucking reason, even after multiple attempts to fix it.

Edit: I don't know wether it is the devs or a nVidia driver update that fixed my problem, but it now works in my old PC. I know for sure that it was a driver update from nVidia that made the game always crash... 

Anyway, I changed my PC (RTX 4080 and Ryzen 7 7800x3D, probably enough to run this game I guess), and had another issue with this same game, causing it to fully use my 32GB of RAM and then crash without even launching. The problem was that the game thought it had to run on the integrated GPU of my CPU, and had to literally go into the BIOS to desactivate it, while uninstalling the drivers for the iGPU in the drivers control pannel. 

It works fine now, and I really enjoy it, but I maintain my negative review because I think a game should be able to run instantly after it is installed, and having to do these types of things to make it work is really not user-friendly. I have the chance to be able to do that because I know how to mess up correctly with computers, but for the others that don't know all this type of stuff, it can be awful to pay a game that you can't play simply because of such poor optimisations, when the game is this old. 

Plus, the support service may not be the worse I've ever seen, but is totally not worth it to loose time to contact them seeing what kind of solutions they have. For my first problem, the people behind it just said to me after sending files about my computer that I had to roll back my nVidia drivers to an older update, which is not a solution in my opinion, but a shitty effortless advice that can cause problems in other games, and in stability of the system overall.

So if you enjoy car games and being a fucking nerd going into stuff deep in your computer to make things work, I recommand this game.

Very good game, driving around very fast fun

Really fun driving sim with lots of ride variety and a huge map. Some strange "side missions" like finding a barn with a car to restore (use the drone to fly around the area) but I guess that adds layers to the game. Works great with the Logitech G920 wheel, pedals and shifter.

For me, this is the best ever Forza Horizon and in terms of the entire Forza catalogue, I put this and Forza Motorsport 4 in their own special category of greatness. There is a good reason that Horizon 4 is still going for quite strong money even now. Bluntly, playing this 137 hours later, I have no appetite yet for FH5 and think it will be a long time until I do.

FH4 has a fantastic line up of cars, amazing variety of roads and challenges and the multiplayer servers are still very active as a result of a great product. Yes it's not the cheapest racing game out there, but it is packed with content and almost infinite playability. 

Even just taking your favourite car for a "Sunday drive" in this game is a pleasure. 

Such as the blueprint feature to let you create your own routes and from there, your own events with so many different cars and classes to choose from. Don't like Horizon's own car classes? No problem. You can make your own.

I recommend saving up just a little bit more and buying the Ultimate Edition. The DLCs are generally quite good value compared to other racing titles.

I'm hoping this isn't peak Forza Horizon as FH6 is in development now, but FH4 will be very hard to beat. My fingers are crossed for Japan to be the final destination, packed with quirky JDM cars and unusual things that Japanese car culture is known and loved for.

Personal opinion, it is a rather entertaining game with amazing graphics. Its pretty easy to farm ingame currency (credit/ cr) and there are a LOT of car varieties, also along with livery designs you can do yourself or use the ones publically shared (which seems to be in most of the games similiar to Horizon 4 :')). There are a lot of activities to do varying from speedtraps to races and etc, and personally the big DLC's (Lego Champions and Fortune Island) arent exactly necessary unless you are the type of person to play a singular game for long periods of time. Overall I would reccommend it to people who are unsure on if they should purchase or not, not very hard to farm cash, not all that complicated.

Edit:  The freezes and crashes are finally fixed now, so I'm recommending again.

Ignore my Steam time.  I've had this on the MS store since launch, but also wanted to buy it here on Steam.  I'm not sure what to say about this game to be honest.  I like it and I also can't stand it.

Pro's:
- Lots of  cars
- Customization
- Housing
- Drag, Drift, Street, Circuit, Sprint races
- Showcase events
- Online group events
- Story chapters, though not really all that interesting to me.  I usually avoid these, aside from the business ones.

Con's:
- Horrible traffic.  Not in the amount of traffic, but in distance that it spawns in.  Clearly imo, traffic is meant to purposely cause accidents and generally annoy players.
- Freeroam is annoying due to traffic.  See above.
- Some events are unreasonably difficult, especially some story chapter events.
- Engine sounds aren't very good in Horizon 4 vs Horizon 3.
- An iffy sense of progression, better than Horizon 5 at least, but far worse the Horizon 3.
- Story chapters range from very boring to pretty decent.  
- Horrible class balance.  Some cars in the same class reach a very high top speed while others are very low; there's no sense of class balance in this game imo.
- No car meet 

So that's pretty much it.  The game is awesome in some areas and horrible in other areas imo.  Forza Horizon 3 is still the better game in comparison to both Horizon 4 and Horizon 5.  

In any case, it's worth buying during or not during a sale.

Forza Horizon has always held a special place in my heart. Forza Horizon 4 has again found that place. Playing this game even as an adult brought back a childish excitement I haven't felt since FH2. 

The graphics are stunning and the changing seasons make the game fun all the time. It's the classic FH experience but with added challenges. The cars look stunning and most of the terrain feels realistic and driveable. The soundtrack is also brilliant, but it does get a little repetitive after a few hours. There's loads of radio stations but very few songs I enjoyed after nearly 600 hours. The challenges and story missions are fun, with the right amount of effort required (in my opinion). The car customisation is also good; I can build my car to be what I want without much limitation to what there is available.

On the downside, there was the issue where the game used to crash without the right graphics driver, but this is fixed.  After that, there was no limit to how much fun I had. I have 100% achievements and look forward to playing FH5. It's perfection, in my opinion. 10/10

This game has seen some much needed improvement since my negative review from nearly a year ago. 
The connection issues seem to have been fixed and the game isn't abandoned as much as I thought. There is still a lot of positive player participation, a lot of updates and events, and surprisingly sees a lot more online player interaction than Forza Horizon 5. 

It would still be nice to have seasons be optional for the general map at least, but I now understand that the seasons are part of the Forza Horizon experience. 

So I've revised my review and actually recommend this one for some fun and engaging racing of various styles.

Forza Horizon 4 is a racing game that sets the gold standard for the genre. It's a symphony of speed, precision, and open-world beauty. The game's attention to detail in recreating the picturesque landscapes of the United Kingdom is awe-inspiring, and the changing seasons add a dynamic element to the races, keeping the gameplay fresh and exciting. The car selection is vast, and the customization options are endless, allowing players to truly make their dream rides. With a seamless online experience and a welcoming community, Forza Horizon 4 delivers an unparalleled racing experience that keeps you coming back for more. It's a masterpiece that every racing enthusiast should have in their collection

[h1] I Drive *Nightcall starts playing*[/h1]
[i] Originally I've reviewed this game as "Do not recommend" because it wasn't launching on my PC at all. 
Now i have a new PC and the game works like a charm, so it warrants a review update. [/i]

Game is really cool, so far I like it. 
Driving feels good, graphics and sound are superb. 

The biggest caveat I have is the amount of paywalls: tons of interesting cars and events are locked behind DLC. I like the approach Gran Turismo 7 took in that regard: all cars are accessible without microtransactions via in-game currency. Would prefer if it was the same way here. Now I wonder if bying Ultimate edition instead of Standard would be a better way.

Overall the game is fun and feels great to drive around in. 
But I'm a fairly casual single-player kind of guy, so have no idea how the online is doing here.
only downsides to this game are that it takes place in england and that every road other than highway roads are 2 lane

Breathtakingly beautiful graphics where you can immerse yourself with a rich and vibrant open world filled with uncountable amount of things you can do. It's such a cozy game to play where there's no pressure of winning or losing because it does not matter, as you are rewarded for simply finishing it.

You get to solely focus on creating and driving your own dream car, find a new one, or try collecting from over 600 cars. With amazing soundtracks, graphics and performance, the Forza Horizon series are a masterpiece when it comes to arcade racing game genre.

The anywhere fast travel is one of the best addition to the game and it really makes a huge difference. I recommend smashing all the 50 fast travel boards so it won't cost you anything to fast travel. There's also other much needed QOL features that were not present in previous games.

If you're buying the game, get the ultimate edition as it adds massive amount of contents to the game

I do not recommend this game if you're here to play dirt racing or if you are focused on road racing in multiplayer. Freeroam rush is just a brainless gamemode that they haven't even bothered to separate from Dirt Adventure (I forgot what it's called) in 5 YEARS of the game release. As for Road adventure, you cannot only play circuit race; you will have to also play street races. Again, they haven't even bothered separate the categories between street racing and circuit racing. If you're trying to use Open season, it's pretty much dead to me if you're trying to play a B-class car in road racing for example, and most likely you will encounter high level player  with A-class car lobby that you barely know anything about tuning

TL;DR
Just get FH5 instead,  just to avoid Freeroam Rush game mode

There is too much BS in this game - you have unskippable cutscenes, you have to wait before a race for some 'witty banter' between characters you don't care about to finish. I also just got an unskippable ad for their microtransaction DLC.  They put the entrances for said DLC in the vanilla game so that you roll up to an event on the map only to find out that you have to pay to participate in it.  It really feels predatory - I want to play a game, not have someone try to mine me for my data and money.  The devs did a good job and there really is a great game underneath all of the tediousness.

When it comes to racing games, there's no better choice than ForzaHorizon 4. It has set the bar for racing games and without a doubt, it's a masterpiece that excels in every aspect.

ForzaHorizon 4 boasts an impressive collection of over 450 cars from different eras, each one meticulously detailed and a joy to drive. You'll never get bored with the diverse range of cars, from sleek supercars to off-road monsters.

The game's recreation of the British countryside is breathtaking, with rolling hills, picturesque villages, and changing seasons that create an ever-evolving racing playground. The dynamic weather system adds a whole new level of excitement, racing through a sudden downpour or navigating icy roads in winter keeps each race fresh and challenging. 

The transition from day to night is seamless and visually stunning. It adds a whole new dimension to gameplay, with the night races being particularly immersive.

ForzaHorizon 4 offers a wide variety of events, from traditional races to stunts and challenges. The extensive car customization options allow you to personalize your vehicles, ensuring that each car feels uniquely yours. 

Playing with friends or joining online events is a blast. The game's online community keeps the action going. In summary, ForzaHorizon 4 is the ultimate racing game experience. It seamlessly combines jaw-dropping visuals, an incredible roster of cars, dynamic weather, and an open world that begs to be explored. Whether you're a casual gamer or a hardcore racing enthusiast, this game has something for everyone. This is not just a game - it's an automotive adventure that you cannot afford to miss! #ForzaHorizon4 #RacingMasterpiece 🚗🌍🌦️🌞🎮🏆

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)

Forza Horizon 4 isn't just a game; it's an automotive symphony that unfolds across the changing seasons of the picturesque British countryside. With 16.4 hours behind the wheel, it's evident that this game isn't just a racing title; it's an exhilarating journey through a dynamic and beautifully rendered world.

The most striking aspect of Forza Horizon 4 is its ever-evolving environment. The game takes place in a shared open-world, where the seasons change not just in appearance but in how they impact your driving experience. The transition from the lush greenery of spring to the icy roads of winter isn't just visual; it changes how each car handles, offering a new dimension of strategy and challenge.

The United Kingdom's countryside is meticulously recreated, offering a diverse and stunning backdrop for your racing adventures. From the rolling hills of the Cotswolds to the city streets of Edinburgh, the attention to detail is nothing short of impressive. It's a world that encourages exploration, with hidden barn finds and stunt jumps waiting to be discovered.

Forza Horizon 4 embraces an accessible but deep racing experience. The game's vast car roster, ranging from vintage classics to modern supercars, ensures there's a vehicle for every taste. The driving physics strike a balance between realism and fun, and players can tailor their driving aids to match their skill level. This adaptability makes the game appealing to both casual players and racing enthusiasts.

The Festival concept, which serves as the game's framework, works brilliantly. The sense of camaraderie and competition among the festival-goers enhances the immersion and the social aspects of the game. You can take part in a variety of events, from traditional races to showcase events that pit you against trains, planes, and even hovercraft.

One of the game's standout features is the ability to create and share custom race routes. This player-generated content adds endless replayability and creativity to the game, allowing you to design your dream racecourses or tackle those crafted by others.

The visuals and audio design of Forza Horizon 4 are top-notch. The game is a visual spectacle, with stunning weather effects, realistic lighting, and breathtaking car models. The engine roars, the tire squeals, and the music selection amplify the sense of exhilaration, creating a truly immersive experience.

While the game is superb, there are a few minor drawbacks. The Drivatar AI can sometimes exhibit overly aggressive behavior, which can be frustrating. Additionally, while the in-game purchases are optional, they are present and could potentially detract from the sense of accomplishment through natural progression.

In conclusion, Forza Horizon 4 is a racing game that transcends the genre. It's a celebration of the joy of driving and exploration, offering an accessible yet deep experience for racing enthusiasts and casual players alike. With its dynamic seasons, diverse car roster, and stunning British landscape, it's a title that keeps you coming back for more. Whether you're a petrolhead or just looking for a good time, Forza Horizon 4 delivers an unforgettable journey through speed and beauty. It's a must-play for anyone who appreciates the art of driving.

Forza Horizon 4 is a dream come true for car lovers across the globe. Featuring an outrageously impressive car roster of over 700 beautifully designed and accurately replicated cars of all types and time periods, a unmatched sense of both Customization and Personalization with untold thousands of possible tune combinations on each car the player is able to get their ride driving in a way that not only fits like a glove over their driving style but complements it. Not to mention with the auction house and wheel spins featured in the game any player can be driving around in a desirable car mere hours after first launch cutting back on the build up and getting the player head deep in those intense races as soon as possible. A beautiful, large, vast and evolving open world designed carefully with all details of driving in mind even the mere sights alone would be enough to keep the player suitably entertained and with fairly priced DLCs that bring more innovation and variety to the racing events available you can truly think you've seen it all in this game and would've barely started. Overall Forza Horizon 4 Is a racing game in which each and every aspect is purely and consummately created around the driving and racing experience.

Hundreds of hours of racing goodness. There is so much content that it can seem daunting at first but eventual you get used to the progression. Don't expect Need For Speed style set races. This is a beautiful open world game with events that you can drop in around the map. You can play each race dozens or even hundreds of times because each style of car makes the race a different experience. Loosely tied in to the Top Gear show, with Chris Harris contributing his voice to a small part of the game - even The Stig makes an appearance! 

I also bought the James Bond car pack that adds about a dozen cars from the Bond movies but there doesn't seem to be any Bond content. Still fun to go bombing around in the DB5 or Wet Nelly.

I do have one big issue. After a few hours of game play I can't play online and can only play with in-game players. Not multiplayer. This is frustrating if you want to play against friends or random strangers. This is a known problem and can be fixed but it involves editing the registry which I find a bit crap to be honest.

There are a lot of perfectly justified reasons to not like this game and it absolutely contains some of the worst aspects of Modern Gaming™.

But damn it is just a blast to drive and in the end that is all that matters. I won't waste any real time reviewing such an old game, but I have Gamepass and think this game may be better than FH5. The setting is much more enjoyable for me. I like the very distinct seasons too.

A breath of fresh air after arcade racing games like Need for Speed and The Crew. Reasonable handling, no nitro, basically no grind, lots of cars and racing scenarios.

One downside — seasons are kind of a drag at this point. To get all season-exclusive cars, one needs to play for more than a year. I wish it was possible to speed them up or choose to do at will, without the rotation.

I Fixed game lol

If you have infinite loading screen issue before you start this game go to nvidia control panel and find:

3D settings -> find vertical sync -> turn ON

apply and ok and start game now!

Now after you hopefully load in game do few races and save new local file/cloud file and exit game 

Go back to Nvidia Control panel but this time disable forced Vsync, hit apply and then ok and steam version should work again but this time without V sync, worked in my case but in worst case scenario you will need to keep v sync on...

I have been playing the Forza series since xbox 360. I have seen the excellent progression in game play, story, graphics and whatnot and I am very impressed with Forza 4. I love the open-world aspect as well as the ability to drive around with random people in the world and race or whatever. Great graphics, Great story, definitely has "replay-ability". Played for a long time on my Xbox and was very excited to see that it had been released on steam. This game really gives you that dopamine fix and the immersion into this world is unreal.
Worth it 100%. 
P.S. I have Horizon 5 as well and I keep coming back to 4.

If you're a die-hard fan of racing games or just someone looking for an adrenaline-pumping virtual experience, Forza Horizon 4 is an absolute must-play. As a seasoned gamer, I've seen my fair share of racing titles, but this one stands out as a true masterpiece that offers not only a top-notch racing experience but also an open-world adventure that's nothing short of breathtaking.

From the moment you fire up the game, you're transported to the picturesque landscapes of Great Britain. The attention to detail is astounding, with the changing seasons adding an unprecedented layer of immersion. The seasons not only alter the appearance of the world but also impact the way you drive, making each season feel like a fresh start in your automotive journey.

The car roster in Forza Horizon 4 is a gearhead's dream come true. With over 700 meticulously crafted cars from various manufacturers, there's something for every automotive enthusiast. Whether you prefer classic muscle cars, sleek hypercars, or off-road monsters, you'll find your dream ride waiting for you. The level of customization available for each vehicle is staggering, allowing you to fine-tune your ride to perfection.

The real star of the show, however, is the open-world environment. The map is a sprawling playground with a diverse range of terrains, from dense forests to serene lakesides and bustling urban streets. The dynamic weather and day-night cycle further enhance the immersive experience. You can explore at your own pace or take part in a multitude of events, from thrilling street races to heart-pounding off-road challenges.

The gameplay in Forza Horizon 4 strikes a perfect balance between realism and accessibility. Hardcore racing fans will appreciate the realistic physics and handling, while newcomers can easily dive in and have a blast. The addition of the Horizon Festival, a celebration of all things automotive, adds a layer of fun and camaraderie that sets this game apart from its competitors.

Multiplayer in Forza Horizon 4 is a highlight as well. Whether you're teaming up with friends for a convoy, competing in seasonal events, or engaging in the pulse-pounding Battle Royale mode, there's no shortage of excitement when it comes to multiplayer action.

Graphically, Forza Horizon 4 is a work of art. The attention to detail in the cars and the environment is jaw-dropping, and the game runs flawlessly even on lower-end systems, thanks to excellent optimization.

In conclusion, Forza Horizon 4 is a masterpiece in the world of racing games. With its stunning visuals, diverse car selection, dynamic open world, and engaging multiplayer, it sets a new standard for the genre. Whether you're a racing aficionado or just looking for some high-octane fun, this game will leave you breathless and craving more. Buckle up, hit the road, and prepare to be swept away by the automotive paradise that is Forza Horizon 4.

Forza Horizon 4 is an absolute blast! The graphics are stunning; the attention to detail in the cars and the changing seasons is mind-blowing. The gameplay strikes a perfect balance between accessibility and challenge, and the dynamic seasons keep things fresh and exciting. The variety of cars and activities is impressive, and the online multiplayer seamlessly integrates with the open world. My only gripe is that the AI of other drivers can be a bit robotic. Overall, Forza Horizon 4 is a must-play for any racing game fan, and it's endlessly replayable. I can't get enough of it!

I first played through this game on the windows store release, and its good to see it out on steam. I would recommend grabbing the ultimate edition on a deep sale, there is a lot of content that i think is worth the extra 10 dollars or so. 

The map in this game may not be as exotic as some others in the series, but I think it is tastefully done and the expansion map destinations are pretty fun. Fortune Island in particular is pretty neat, sort of a north sea island setting. 

Performance wise the game is pretty good, similar to the other games available on PC. Pretty good visuals for the time it released and still looks great compared to contemporary titles. well optimized and flexible on a variety of hardware. I have not encountered any bugs of note in this game, and it has been very stable. 

I really enjoy the balance they strike with the handling model in these games. If you have liked the previous titles (or even FH5) I think this one slots into your collection just fine.

Sooo... I love this game. It is probably the best Forza Horizon, and I love all of them.
So why the thumbs down? Because MS/Playground seem to not give a flying <bleep> about the bugs they left in the game for years, never bothering to fix them. Online racing is borderline impossible as you sit there looking at a load screen for 10 minutes every time (no I'm not exaggerating). The same thing happens in any of the story missions if you choose replay. The only way to avoid it there is to quit and load the same mission again, which often involves driving to a faraway destination in a slow car before you can attempt the actual mission objective, and/or you have to sit through unskippable cutscenes every time.
If you enjoy arcade racers and don't mind only playing solo (or are very patient) then this is still an easy recommendation, but publishers/devs should not keep getting away with stuff like this.

and just to cut it to the chase, some cars will be almost impossible to acquire.
They were focusing too much on player retention rather than giving a shorter and more enjoyable experience of the game.

Ehh, Horizon (4)... UK countryside, sheep and McLaren... shoud've been a total vibe, a slam dunk. And it is NOT.

Was pretty torn wether to set it as a positive or a negative review. Well, there is a lot to love, and a lot bringing it down. From full bliss to total cringe, swinging constantly.

Let's put it this way: Horizon 4 is an amazing car sandbox and an ugly mess of a racing game.

Amazing handling model, easy to pick up, yet pretty deep and realistic enough, and given the massive car list with the amount of performance upgrade and tuning available, that is a massive achievement.
The map is just breathtaking with tons of goodies to explore... found myself taking photos herding sheep with a Jeep just for vibes.

On the other hand the campaign progression is practically non-existent. A very hype intro, a long and extremely hand-holding tutorial, where it gradually opens up and starts showering you with wheelspins: random chance of cars/credits/vanity items. You could get the fastest hypercars in the 1st hour if RNG decides to bless/curse you with it and get showered with tens of cars almost instantly. This practically killed any sense of progress and meaningful achievement for me. And I specifically picked 4 over 5 as my first Forza Horizon game hoping it's not as much of a vapid instant gratification BS. Like this is a AAA racing game, right? Not a free-to-play gatcha colectathon, then why that vibe of those with gambling and addiction mechanics? At least no paid loot boxes, so fine I guess.
Still almost ragequited when seeing the McLaren F1's pricetag... bit over the 1mil mark, around the same as NFS Unbound, but that was a fair grind given the car's power and IRL heritage, here it looked disrespectfully low compared to the tempo of the in-game economy.
Oh well, there are tons of small metrics acting as branching paths of bucket lists to carve your adventure on the festival, so there is much fun to be had after that initial shock.

AI opponents are a mess. As much as the Drivatar system is some real tech wizardry, it results in little more than an overengineered perlin-noise for a dumb core system tugging them along a sloppily programmed racing line.
Another retard mistake is, how if you turn on damage simulation, it only gets applied to you, not the AI. On an offroad race, I always pulled ahead in lap1 EZ, but they always caught up and gained unreasonable lead later. That's when I realised, the unavoidable big jump only decreased my engine performance, not theirs. How do mistakes of this caliber don't get noticed by QA before release in a series of this pedigree!?

So, very strong foundations in world design and the cars, unlimited amounts of fun. And all that gets soured by ton's of stupid stuff I can't comprehend how a developer on this level can make. Still, that core is so strong it won't make me regret the purchase or stop playing. But as popular as it got, the Horizon series is not perfect by a long shot.

[h1][u][b]"Forza Horizon 4: Where I Went from Backseat Driver to Backflip Expert!"[/b][/u][/h1]

If you've ever dreamed of taking your grandma's vintage sedan for a spin on a Scottish countryside, only to end up doing a triple backflip off a cliff, then Forza Horizon 4 is the game you never knew you needed in your life!

I stumbled into Forza Horizon 4 expecting a relaxing Sunday drive through picturesque landscapes. Little did I know, I'd soon be soaring through the air like a caffeinated seagull on a Red Bull binge!

The game starts with you, a normal human being with a questionable driver's license, being dropped into the British countryside with a car that has more horsepower than the entire cast of Fast & Furious combined. You're immediately given the keys to the kingdom (or rather, the ignition to your dream car) and told to go forth and conquer the open-world map. And conquer I did!

But don't let the lush meadows and quaint villages fool you; this game is a certified adrenaline junkie's paradise. One minute, you're cruising down a narrow country lane, narrowly avoiding sheep, and the next, you're drifting through ancient stone circles like a modern-day Druid.

And the cars! Oh, the cars! Forza Horizon 4 has more cars than a parking lot at a Justin Bieber concert. From vintage classics to hypercars that make your heart race faster than a cheetah with an energy drink addiction, there's a vehicle for every type of player. You can even customize them to your heart's content, as long as your heart's content includes neon pink paint and a spoiler that could double as an aircraft wing.

The game's weather system is like Mother Nature on a rollercoaster binge. One moment, you're racing under sunny skies, and the next, you're hydroplaning through a monsoon that would put Noah's flood to shame. It's all part of the fun and keeps you on your toes, or rather, your tires.

Forza Horizon 4 also has a knack for turning the most mundane objects into potential launch ramps. Stone walls, farmhouses, and innocent pedestrians all become part of your high-octane playground. Just remember to apologize to the sheep if you accidentally launch them into low Earth orbit.

But it's not all chaos and mayhem. The game also has a fantastic music lineup that caters to every taste, from classical to hip-hop. You can choose your own soundtrack or just listen to the in-game radio. And honestly, nothing beats drifting through the Scottish Highlands while listening to Beethoven's 9th Symphony. It's a cultural experience like no other.

In conclusion, Forza Horizon 4 is not just a game; it's a wild, hilarious, and occasionally heart-stopping adventure through the British countryside. It's the kind of game that turns your driving skills from "Sunday driver" to "X Games contender." So, if you've ever wanted to explore the UK with a turbocharged rocket strapped to your back, this game is for you. Just remember to fasten your seatbelt, because things are about to get bumpy in the best way possible!

"Forza Horizon 4" is an impressive open-world racing game that offers a fantastic experience for racing enthusiasts. Here are some positive and negative aspects of the game:

Positive Aspects:

Visual Splendor: The game's graphics are exceptional. The stunning landscapes of England, dynamic seasonal changes, and detailed vehicle designs provide players with an immersive visual experience.

Open World Exploration: The game features an open-world map, allowing players to freely explore different regions of England. This enhances the joy of exploration and free driving.

Wide Range of Vehicles: "Forza Horizon 4" boasts a vast selection of licensed vehicles, each offering a different driving experience. It includes both classic cars and supercars, catering to a wide range of preferences.

Online Modes: The game offers various multiplayer modes, allowing you to participate in races or cooperative gameplay with other players. You can race against friends or engage with the online community.

Negative Aspects:

Some Repetition: The game can sometimes include repetitive elements in races and missions, which may lead to a sense of monotony for some players.

Difficulty Balance: Some players may find that the game's difficulty balance can be occasionally unfair, with varying difficulty levels across different races.

However, overall, "Forza Horizon 4" delivers a high-quality gaming experience that will satisfy racing game enthusiasts. Its stunning visuals, expansive open world, and diverse vehicle selection make it a game you'll want to play for a long time.

Forza Horizon 4 is one of my favorite racing games, if not favorite games of all time. After playing for roughly 30 hours on PC and 60 hours on Xbox, I can confidently say this game is a must-play. Detailed breakdown follows:

GRAPHICS
Literally looks like real life, outside of the character models. But thankfully we're just focusing on cars in this game. 9.5/10

GAMEPLAY
Fun, reactive gameplay from the different cars available to drive. I really enjoyed how cars with power steering control differently from those without, definitely adds to the realism and shows Playground's attention to detail in crafting the game. Cars perform differently depending on the upgrades and tuning that are installed, and you can easily spend hours in the upgrade menus just experimenting with different builds. There's also a tuning share feature where you can download other players' builds, though unfortunately it doesn't let you expand off of those downloaded builds. 9.5/10

STORY
Forza Horizon 4 continues the series' tradition of forgoing a traditional story mode in favor of multiple side story quests that help you level up and earn rewards. From stunt driving for a movie to escorting people in a souped-up taxicab, the side missions really add some fun to the game outside of normal exhibition races.  8/10

ONLINE
I don't play too much online, mainly because of the community and the fact that Microsoft will ban you for sneezing in the wrong direction. I only play online if I'm testing out drag racing builds with friends. 6/10

BUGS/OPTIMIZATION
Very few bugs. Granted I am reviewing this 5 years after the game launched but the point still stands. The game has always been fairly polished and never felt like a chore to play. Only massive bug I've experienced was jumping off a ramp and then my car clipped through and fell through the map. After about 4 seconds, the car respawned on solid ground. Other than that, nothing to report in the way of bugs. 9.5/10

DLC/MONETIZATION
The game is heavily monetized as is the case with most of Microsoft's games. However, the monetization never feels intrusive. You can still have a great experience without the DLC cars or world expansions. I didn't even have DLC access until I purchased the Deluxe Edition on sale here on Steam. But I can see why people wouldn't like cars that can give you a competitive advantage in multiplayer locked behind a paywall. 8/10

VERDICT
Forza Horizon 4 is definitely the best in the series and my personal favorite racing game of all time. I can definitely see myself playing this for years to come.  8.4/10

It's a very fun game.....when I can actually play it.... Other than that it constantly crashes on the Steam Deck, and no amount of adjustments or supposed fixes actually fixes it. It usually will crash after a few minutes of me being in a menu of some kind, like the auction house or map. After the first crash it will then struggle to even launch and just repeatedly crash 6+ times before it decides to actually work..for a little while. Then it repeats the crashing fit.

This game has everything! For people who like to chill and drive in a large open world, this is perfect. I am new to the horizon series, I was confused whether to buy Forza Horizon 4 or Forza Horizon 5 , I bought Forza Horizon 4 and I would say that this was THE perfect beginning. I love to race sometimes, and the races are just perfect. The terrain for off-roading is also very detailed, and highly enjoyable. You can customize a lot about the cars in general and tune it to your liking. In my opinion Forza Horizon 4 is still a good place to start, if you are new to the horizon series. I highly recommend this game to anyone who is interested to join the Horizon series or just anyone who is interested in driving.

Being my first time experiencing a Forza Horizon game with 4, I can safely say this is the most fun I've had in years while playing a racing game.

This feels like an actual automotive fantasy powetrip put into play, with so many cars to drive and collect, different kinds of events and activities to try out and experiment while driving on a really nice looking and overall fun map to explore, with the weather dynamic changing the map ever so slightly every week, which keeps the game fresh.

All of this brought out with the most satisfying driving model and physics I've experienced in a modern arcade racing game, with some foot ground on the arcade-sim like but with its notches dialed up for the fun aspect, make this a really strong title. 

Some of my grips with the game come from the story/campaign (or lack thereof), issues with the multiplayer and online connectivity, and the progression systems that feels mostly tied to the wheelspin mechanic, however the core gameplay and feel of the game is so good, that I'm able to overlook these issues and still have a great time with the game, even if I was late to the party.
