Long story short, 9/10. Amazing experience with this game!

Graphics: 10/10
No of Cars: 10/10
Handling: 8/10
Story/Progression system: 7/10
Online/Multiplayer: 2/10 - Just horrible. Load times take forever. Sometimes unfair team distribution.
Car Customisation: 5/10 - It is nothing when compared to NFS titles (except some)
Car Upgrading & Performance tuning: 9/10 - Feels so real when you see every stat you change is affecting how the car handles.
Map: 8/10 - Great!
DLCs (Fortune Island + LEGO): 8/10 - Worth buying. Provides so much playtime but lets be real though, kinda feels boring when you have to do repetitive things.

AI Difficulty/ Drivatars: When set to Highly Skilled and above, there is a bug with the AI especially the one who is in the first place. You have to catch up to him in the very beginning of the race or else you will never be able to pass him. He will be miles ahead of you and the rest of the pack of racers.
Secondly, Drivatars don't follow the rules of physics that apply to your car. They will turn at greater speeds than you with losing speed, won't skid or anything like that whereas you'll be sliding left and right and colliding way to often if you try to imitate them. So, in conclusion, NEVER EVER set the difficulty of the Drivatars above Highly Skilled if you plan to have a good time with the game and not just go ranting left and right about it to everyone and everywhere.

Car/ engine sounds: 7/10 - Not always accurate for every car: A hatch-back random Renault car from the story was sounding like BMW M3 GTR from NFS MW '05

Conclusion: If you are planning to buy this game on full price, NO! Rather buy Forza Horizon 5. Only worth buying ON SALE.

Forza Horizon 4 isn't just a game; it's an automotive masterpiece that takes the racing genre to new heights. From the moment I revved up my engine, I was captivated by the sheer beauty and depth this game has to offer.

The first thing that struck me was the breathtaking open-world environment. The fictionalized rendition of Great Britain is a sight to behold, with picturesque landscapes that transition seamlessly from the historic city streets to the serene countryside. Dynamic weather and seasonal changes add a layer of realism that I've never experienced in a racing game before. Whether it's a summer breeze or a snowy blizzard, the world feels alive and constantly evolving.

The car roster is a dream come true for any gearhead. The meticulous attention to detail in each vehicle is awe-inspiring; you can practically hear the engines roar as you accelerate through the diverse array of races and challenges. The progression system is well-balanced, allowing both casual and hardcore players to find their own pace. Whether you're a fan of street racing, off-road adventures, or just cruising around, Forza Horizon 4 has something for everyone.

The Festival atmosphere adds a unique layer of excitement. The events are varied and creatively designed, ensuring that monotony never creeps in. Teaming up with friends for cooperative challenges or engaging in nail-biting PvP races in the shared world is an absolute blast. The seamless online integration is a testament to Playground Games' commitment to delivering an unparalleled multiplayer experience.

What truly sets Forza Horizon 4 apart is the level of customization. You're not just modifying your cars; you're crafting a personal identity. The ability to create custom paint jobs, tunes, and even your own races injects a sense of ownership that extends beyond the virtual garage.

However, it's the attention to player feedback that truly shines. The developers have shown an ongoing commitment to improvement, frequently adding new cars, events, and features through updates. This dedication to enhancing the game's content and addressing community concerns speaks volumes about the team behind it.

Forza Horizon 4 is a masterpiece that elevates the racing genre to unparalleled heights. It's a visual and auditory feast that caters to both casual players and hardcore racers. The seamless blend of stunning visuals, exhilarating gameplay, and a thriving online community make it a must-play for any gamer, even if you're not traditionally a racing enthusiast. Jump into the driver's seat and get ready for a journey through a racing paradise that you won't want to end.

Since I own both FH4 and FH5, I figured I'd write one review for both, copy & paste, so folks can have a comparison.

Recommend? Yes. Hands down the best racing game I've ever played in my life. The sheer amount of content, the seamless multiplayer (esp. in FH5), the magnitude of things to do, along with the PERFECT racing feel have all conspired to make this easily the best racing experience I've ever had.

It is WONDERFUL that this game is not plagued with "pay to win," and that you don't have to be level one million to have great cars. You can get some pretty fantastic cars fairly early on, so when you're racing against others, if you lose you know it's not necessarily because the other players have spent 17 billion years playing. (Although, of course, it will take a LONG time to get ALL the cars.)

So what's the basic gameplay? Well, you're a driver. You're in a huge, open-world map. You drive around, you enter races, you do tricks/stunts, you play missions, all kinds of stuff. You earn money and experience doing so, and use that money to... buy new cars. You then race those cars to... earn more money. While in the open map, you're in a playground with the other players (and it's such a nice turn of pace that you can't crash each other in the open world). When racing, you can race against AI, other players, whatever you want.

There are a ton of different race types - road, dirt, off-road, street (where normal traffic is left on the roads) and more. There are co-op races and pvp races, and each is fantastic in its own right. There are "games" you can play (various co-op "car tag" type games). There are "stunt" zones where you might try to earn high scores with speed, drifting, jumps, and more. There are storyline missions - and while the "stories" aren't very deep, they're certainly fun. Basically, there's just... no end of stuff to do.

This is only made more fun by the "seasons." Each week is a new "season" (summer, winter, etc in FH4 and wet, dry, et in FH5). There are 4 seasons in each round, and during those different seasons there are "seasonal events" you can participate in to earn a ton of bonus stuff - so every week, you've got brand new ways to race, earn experience, win cars, and more. Plus, that means that each week the scenery and road conditions change!

There are "upgrades." Yes, you can add/remove/tune all kinds of parts in your car to upgrade/downgrade it. Some folks spend a TON of time on this... others, like me, mainly just download fits/tunes made by other players. So if you don't feel like spending forever tinkering, you can do like I do and just browse others' tunes.

You can play pre-made routes, or create your own. Some players spend a ton of time creating really interesting routes... so even after you've raced the included races a billion times, there's still endless content for you to enjoy with more coming.

Plus, Forza works on Steam Deck. It says unsupported, but it works. (Well, FH4 took a dump on me for a couple weeks at one point & wouldn't launch.. but works again) SD tips: set the game to run on Proton Experimental. Set your SD options to cap the framerate to 30FPS. Set resolution to 1280x800 and set graphics pre-sets to high. In game, set the FPS limit to 60 and see if it runs well for you; if not, set it to 30FPS. WIth these settings I have been able to play just fine.

The racing "feel" is just flawless. One of my favorite parts of Just Cause 3 and GTA V are the driving, because it just "feels" so natural. You don't spend a ton of time trying to "get" the controls... you just kind of ease into them and you're off. It's JUST like that in Forza Horizon. I never feel like I didn't win a race because I was "cheated" or fighting the controls. (Only side note - the drift mechanics feel a little bleh in FH4, especially with the scoring, but it still feels just right.)

Interaction between players is fun & fair. You can honk at each other or use little phrases with each other. In open world, you're in "ghost" mode & can't wreck each other. You can play around but not screw each other up. In co-op games you can make contact, but go ghost if you're in some kind of situation where things could be unfair (eg if I'm screaming up behind you & don't see that you're stopped, one of us will go ghost so I don't totally knock you to the moon). Other games are full contact, such as the "games" mini games (of which there are several). So, honestly, the multiplayer aspects are just fantastic - we can get all the feel of driving/racing around with each other, without tons of griefers.

Another thing that's really fun is that NOT... ever car is a "super" car. You play some games where every car in the game is on a slider from "high end" to "space shuttle".. but this game features LOADS of different types of cars so you can jump in on any race experience you want. With the LOADS of racing styles and TONS of different car types (from "can barely move down the road" to "I think I just hit light speed), you can participate in just about any type of race you want.

AND... the stats on the car actually MATTER. Plenty of race games, I more or less ignore the car stat ratings, but whatever the case is, this game will actually have you browsing through your hundreds of cars, trying to pick the right vehicle for the task at hand.

So what are the differences?

FH4 takes places in the UK; FH5 takes place in Mexico. Generally speaking, FH5 is "slightly better" in nearly all regards to FH4. This doesn't mean FH4 sucks by any means; I love the series so much I still regularly play FH4 all the time and complete all the seasonal events. It's like if your favorite pizza is Super Supreme but you still like taco pizza. Most of the time you'll get the supreme.. but you still love taco and eat it for variety. I spend ost of my time in FH5, but still have lots of fun in 4.

There are over 700 cars in each. The maps in FH5 are a little bigger. The mountains, etc seem a little taller. The graphics in 4 are amazing; the graphics in 5 are phenomenal. Sounds in 4 are great... in 5 they blow me away. Multiplayer in 4 is pretty reliable but occasionally lags or gets stuck... MP in 5 is just about as seamless as it gets. Add-on content is slightly more fun in 5. Custom content (custom routes, etc) are a little more abundant in 5. Menus, options, etc are a little cleaner and more easy to navigate in 5. Drifting scoring is a lot more fun in 5. 4 has a great mix of curvy, dirt, and straights... But in FH5, they built in an extra long stretch of straight road for those folks who really want to put their rides to the test. There are also more places to interact with non-driving content (eg. auto show to buy cars, places to upgrade/tune) in FH5... and there's even a "test track" where you can work on car fits, drive a little, work some more, drive a little. It makes upgrading slightly easier in 5.

Overall, I would say start with 5 if you're on the fence. Even if FH4 is on sale & FH5 isn't, I'd still recommend 5 just because the edge 5 has on 4 is significant enough to really make a difference. AGAIN, not saying 4 is "bad." I would also recommend buying the full package, or premium, or whatever the heck it was called. You really do get a TON more bang for your buck. I would also recommend owning the DLC's - they are a blast in their own right, and add additional seasonal events as well in both 4 & 5!!

Would I recommend waiting for sale vs paying full price? Well, I bought both on sale... but as big a fan as I am of these worlds, I would easily recommend playing full price, no questions asked. Yes, it's a little steep, but so worth it. HOWEVER, if you're strapped for cash, just add it to your wishlist & wait. These titles go on sale (for a pretty decent discount) fairly often.

Yes, these two titles are going to be my FAVORITE racing ones of all time... Until FH6 comes along, of course.

IF YOU PLAY WITH THE STEERING WHEEL DON'T BUY THIS GAME ON STEAM, IT'S A BROKEN SCAM HERE!!!

The Steam version of FH4 and MS Store version are TWO DIFFERENT VERSIONS. MS Store version works perfectly fine, but the steam one have 10 degree, baked in, permanent deadzone with deadzone being set to 0 in game options, nothing can fix it, and nobody apparently, even the developer. Another thing that is broken in the Steam Edition is the H/stick shifter! I thought that FH4 in general had a problem with a shifter being connected separately... but since I bought the Microsoft Store version I know that's not true as... As the moment I started playing the MS Store version not only the dreadful deadzone was gone, but also, my Thrustmaster shifter started magically working! So yea, Steam version of FH4 is a broken scam, don't buy it here, if you intend to play it with the wheel, like me.

I wasted a lot of time on the Steam version, and finally reached the breaking point and got the MS Store one and all the infuriating problems vanished, but I have to start over, all my over 500 cars gone, all my houses gone, all the credits gone, everything, had to start from scratch. Don't be like me thinking you can take the 10 degree deadzone, you can't, it drives like crap. Just wait for a promotion on MS Store or buy a gamepass.

PS: Just so you know, FH 5 works perfectly fine on Steam however, no deadzone, shifter works as intended... althought it loads for ages after launch. Noticed that FH4 from the MS Store launches 10 times as fast as the Steam version tho, wonder if it's the same case for MS S. FH5 version too, but not wasting my money on potential faster launch load times.
PS2: got to test FH5 Microsoft version and it loads in similar time and runs the same, so it's safe to buy FH5 on Steam.

PS2: The Dev's response is an automated one, unrelated to anything mentioned in this review. FH4 on Steam got a loads of bad reviews because it was unplayable for literally few months on Nvidia graphic cards, so I guess they just add that automatic response to every negative review now. All the problems mentioned in this review still persist and will persist forever, there either is no possibility to fix them in the Steam version, or no will to do it from the Dev's.

Likes about the game:
* Fantastic racing gameplay with off-roading capabilities
* Enjoyable racing and driving experience
* Car customizations are a highlight
* Some of the music in the game is enjoyable

Dislikes about the game:
* Server issues and glitches (though not critical to gameplay)
* Mixed feelings about the music selection

Overall, Forza Horizon 4 offers a fantastic racing experience with the added fun of off-roading. The game features enjoyable racing and driving mechanics, along with extensive car customization options. While there are some server issues and glitches, they don't significantly impact the overall gameplay experience. The music selection is a bit hit or miss, with some tracks being enjoyable while others may not be to everyone's taste.

Racing is good and all but I won't even talk about it, as I bought the game with multiplayer in mind ... turns out multiplayer racing in FH4 is unplayable. Haven't even managed to unlock ranked adventure since finding and/or completing enough unranked races is impossible. 

The load times of multiplayer events are so ridiculous I'm starting to question if there's only a single server running one race at a time for all players. 20-30 minutes is nothing just to get to race once - mind you an adventure has 3+ races, and the wait is the same between them. I did my laundry, prepared lunch and read a bunch of reddit troubleshooting posts in detail while witnessing the game only proceed from "players getting rewards" waiting lobby onto a "fast-traveling other players" loading screen before calling it quits. 

There's also other horseshit such as the game making you wait just to load you into an event that just finished - which means you just went through the whole process of waiting the match to finish and to hand out rewards to the players, just to start all over again.

Oh yeah, and there's no proper lobby selection possibility. You just press a button to search for a race and hope to god the little lonesome server isn't too badly on fire at the moment.

Unless you like open world driving games, do not buy Forza Horizon 4. The only thing it's good for is being an open world driving game, everything else is horrendous. Online is terrible, weekly challenges are the worst, and championships are dry and infuriating. There is nothing rewarding about this game, other than just driving in different cars and doing the occasional race.

Don't do the challenges. Do the races, but nothing else. The challenges are terribly designed so that you waste hours upon hours of your time trying to earn some random car or reward only for the game to withhold it from you for no reason. Upon first look, the game has lots of content, which is not untrue. But the "content" is just a bunch of different ways for you to waste your time on. The only reason you should ever do the challenges is if they're fun, but oftentimes they are not. The issue with the challenges is that they are very unclear and sometimes just outright broken. Sometimes you'll complete a challenge and despite knowing for a fact that you did what they wanted you to do, you still won't get the reward and the game will say the challenge hasn't been completed. Other times you'll have no idea how to even [i]do[/i] the challenge, or you'll think you know how to do it but it still won't work.

Other annoying things:

-Queuing for an online match gets cancelled if you don't return to freeroam within 10 seconds, which would be easy if the menu system wasn't an absolute nightmare. Especially annoying since you have to wait a few minutes to even connect to a match.
-Can't mute players and their ****** dog
-Sometimes you get a 1+ minute ad right as you open up the game. Not even free games do this.
-Used to crash frequently for no reason
-Fast travelling costs credits, which is fine, but it even costs credits to fast travel to your home, which is already useless enough as it is
-The rewind is so needlessly slow. Like, it's for rewinding when you mess up, why does it need to be in slow motion? Even worse, it's incredibly janky and sometimes doesn't work for no reason. 
-Weekly challenges are horribly janky, unpleasant, and unbalanced. You'll spend an hour trying to complete one, only for it to stop updating your progress, so nothing you do works. Or you'll be 3/4 of the way through one and it'll give you a challenge that you can't even do because you haven't unlocked the event. It's so bad that only 9.3% of players have completed one.
-It automatically connects you to a server in [i]freeroam[/i], so you'll just lag randomly, even when playing by yourself. Literally the only thing you can do with other players in freeroam is challenge them to a race, which is entirely car-dependent.
-The menus are a pain to navigate because there'll be submenus within other completely unrelated submenus and there are soo many submenus. Literally more than half the main menu is just for DLCs or useless stuff.
-There are so many needless and annoying prompts and menus. Trying to actually do something using the menus takes forever.
-Has problems saving, so every so often you'll unlock something you've already unlocked, or events will say new even if you've already completed them

All in all, I'd never pay $80 for a game as tedious and unpleasant as this one. There are free games with far better user-friendliness, UI, and overall quality than Forza Horizon 4.

This is—I don't know how many times I've played racing games—but it's my first time playing with a game controller and an ultra-large screen. This is truly a brilliant game. I still remember when I bought it in May of last year. I didn't have my desk and the large monitor for gaming yet. I played with a keyboard and mouse, eventually putting it aside. However, this year, in 2023, I have all of these setups. I have to say, I'm not typically someone interested in game plots, but I was drawn in by the storyline of Forza Horizon 4. 

Here, you can drive freely anywhere you want, embarking on your adventure. You can take part in races or simply admire the scenery. Unlocking new areas has become so addictive. You might, after countless near misses (because I'm not used to driving on the left side of the road), suddenly discover a new villa. It could be near the carnival or offer a great view of the lake. What's more, you can open the map and set your destination, just like how I used to play GTA when I was young. Drive to that location and suddenly touch a memory from back then. 

I want to say it's really a brilliant game, just like every time I go past an electronics shop and see the Xbox demo for Forza Horizon; I'm always captivated. Perhaps, on some future day, I'll join the autumn competition with my newly acquired simulated steering wheel and car seat.

Despite YouTubers moaning the game is surprizingly fun. The customization, although quite in depth when it comes to the mechanical side, the visual customization might feel limited in some cars (especially if you come from nfs/older forza motorsports). I have enjoyed my time completing challenges and races of all kinds with the only exception those that are located within the city center, its bad enough that 90% of the players drive on the right side of the road, having to get used to narrow(-er) AND left side driving in city roads on a circuit where there are AI cars....ain't it. Not bad enough to give the game a bad score or anything...just mildy annoying for the 5-7 races that are located there. Nature in the game looks beautful, cars are very well modeled and yet surprizigly the game runs very well on a system that has aged quite a bit (1050ti,3600x amd and 16g RAM) with mixed (mostly high) settings. If i had to make a criticism it would be physics, although rewarding and well balanced between arcade and sim id say the cars feel quite understeery, that wouldnt be a problem if the AI didnt feel as if it was on rails compared to you at the highest difficulty settings (could bypass it by following broken/competetive setups-builds from the internet but...come on...).

TL;DR:
Game good, car go vroom, racing good, understeery physics on mid-higher end classes, gorgeous visuals, will run decently on an aged/underpowered system.

I've been reluctant to purchase Forza Horizon 4 because of its arcade nature. Unfortunately, eventually I have fallen for great reviews on this game. 

Here is my take on it:
- The good: good graphics, lots of vehicles.
- The bad: yep, this is definitely not a racing simulator. If that's what you are looking for, my advise - look elsewhere. This is an arcade all right. Nothing wrong with this, just different type of a game.

However, here is the really bad part: racing wheel support. Yes, it is the worst I've ever seen, even going quite far back in time. I have a G27 racing wheel. In Forza Horizon 4,  all pedals are mixed up - break pedal accelerates, accelerator pedal brakes, clutch pedal does not work at all. The worst thing is the steering wheel force feedback is reversed. I.e. when you turn, the wheel is fighting you trying to increase the steering angle, which makes it completely undrivable. I've seen tons of complaints about this issue. It seems that it is PC related. The good news - it is fixable. It can't be fixed via menu but if you unpack some game zip file, edit XML configuration file for your wheel and repack it back to the zip file - you can get this to work...  But come on! Doing this sort of thing in a $60 game in 2023??? Seriously?

Also, there is no way to switch off some highly annoying music (radio) from the game settings menu... Imagine this - you can change the radio volume from 10 down to...  1! Which means that it will still be annoying you, you can't shut it off completely at all! Apparently, you are supposed to go to your car, and then flip "radio channels" until it says "radio off"...  Who made this game? 

As you can expect after reading all this, none of the cut scenes (and there are a lot of them) are skippable. You have to sit and listen to some amazing plot (I'm very, very sarcastic) being slowly unraveled for you...

So, on the scale of 1-10, I would give it a solid 4, slightly less than glamorous 9.5 reviews that prompted me to purchase it...

Cheers!

Forza Horizon 4 is a masterpiece, probably the best modern open-world arcade racing game out there. The visuals are breathtaking and each week of the month Britain is different, due to changing seasons giving the world a fresh look. The game offers over 700 cars, lets you tune them and change the liveries as you want. Cars handling feels great, nowhere near Dirt Rally level obviously, but still pretty solid. Soundtrack is good, but I wish it had more songs as they get repetitive after a while. Throughout the world there are a lot of stuff to do; from races, to exploring sites and gathering collectibles, to drifting, hourly and weekly events, story-based challenges, crossover events like Halo, battle royale competitions etc. Also, community is pretty active, there are many people online even at 1-2am. Often, I launch the game just to cruise around while listening to music, it's relaxing.

There are some issues however.
[list]
    [*]Despite support team being responsive, devs failed to address Nvidia driver issues and broken achievements for a long time (they did fix the issues eventually). Problems like Explorer level 29 remain unfixed though.
    [*]FH4 has in-game credits (easy to earn 30-50M a month), but thankfully no microtransactions. However, certain DLCs (like Hot Wheel cars) are locked behind paywall, even for Ultimate edition owners who are supposed to get all content (or so I thought). Pretty greedy move.
    [*]Lego DLC is great, my little brother loves it. But, it has many grindy challenges and requires 100% completion to unlock the final race. It'd had been better if the whole world was made of Legos, kinda ruins the immersion.
    [*]Custom track design and blueprint is quite limited compared to FH5
    [*]Online multiplayer is absolutely dogshit. Sometimes it randomly disconnects, many times you are stuck at loading screen between races for 15-20mins. Singleplayer is a blast, but multiplayer is very frustrating.
[/list]

Title: The Ultimate Racing Experience Gets Even Better - Bought it Twice!

Rating: ★★★★★

Forza Horizon 4 has taken the open-world racing genre and elevated it to an unprecedented level of excitement and entertainment. So much so, that I couldn't resist diving into its automotive wonderland not once, but twice! I initially purchased this masterpiece from the Microsoft Store, and when it finally graced the shelves of Steam, I didn't hesitate to add it to my collection once again.

From the very first rev of the engine to the heart-pounding finish line moments, Forza Horizon 4 is an absolute triumph. The meticulously crafted world of Britain, rendered with stunning detail and dynamic seasons, feels alive as you race through bustling cities, serene countrysides, and everything in between. The transition between seasons is nothing short of breathtaking, altering the driving experience and challenging your skills in ways you'd never expect.

The variety of cars available is a car enthusiast's dream come true. Whether you're tearing through a dirt trail in a rally car or hitting the asphalt in a hypercar, the handling and responsiveness are a testament to the developers' dedication to authenticity. The thrill of discovering and adding new cars to your garage is an addictive journey of its own, keeping you hooked on the pursuit of that perfect ride.

Multiplayer mode is where Forza Horizon 4 truly shines. The seamless integration of online and offline gameplay creates a dynamic social environment that's never short on adrenaline-fueled fun. Joining friends in the open world, participating in races, or tackling challenges together adds an immersive layer of camaraderie that keeps you coming back for more. The seasonal events and ever-evolving content ensure that there's always something new to experience.

As if the core game wasn't enough, the PC version on Steam brings additional benefits that only enhance the experience. From the ease of use to the familiar integration with the Steam ecosystem, it's an absolute joy to have Forza Horizon 4 in my Steam library.

In conclusion, Forza Horizon 4 is more than just a game; it's an automotive masterpiece that continues to captivate and enthrall players. The fact that I couldn't resist buying it twice, once on the Microsoft Store and then on Steam, speaks volumes about the game's quality and longevity. If you're a fan of racing games, or even if you're new to the genre, don't miss out on the chance to experience the unparalleled thrill of Forza Horizon 4. It's a journey worth taking, over and over again.

yes best driving game of all time

Forza Horizon 4 is a breathtaking tour de force that catapults players into the heart of a dynamic and exhilarating automotive wonderland. Developed by Playground Games, this masterpiece of a racing game takes the acclaimed Forza franchise to new heights, earning its well-deserved 5-star rating through a stunning blend of realism, variety, and sheer driving joy.

From the moment you step foot into the picturesque landscapes of the United Kingdom, you're greeted by an awe-inspiring open world that seamlessly shifts through the four seasons. This dynamic weather system doesn't just serve as a visual spectacle, but significantly affects the gameplay and driving conditions. Racing through autumn leaves, navigating icy roads in winter, and feeling the sun's warmth in summer—each season brings its own unique challenges and experiences, keeping the game fresh and engaging.

The attention to detail in Forza Horizon 4 is nothing short of astounding. The meticulously rendered environments, from the bustling city streets of Edinburgh to the serene beauty of the countryside, are a testament to the developers' commitment to creating a lifelike world. The realistic lighting, weather effects, and the way the environment reacts to your every move contribute to an immersive experience that's unparalleled.

The car roster is a car enthusiast's dream come true. With an extensive collection of meticulously recreated vehicles, ranging from sleek supercars to vintage classics, there's something to cater to every taste and preference. The level of detail in the car models and the way they handle on the road mirrors the real world, making the driving experience incredibly authentic. Customization options allow you to fine-tune your favorite rides, adding a personal touch to your automotive adventures.

One of the standout features of Forza Horizon 4 is the Horizon Life campaign, which seamlessly integrates single-player and multiplayer experiences. Engaging in a variety of events, races, and challenges not only advances your progression but also connects you with an online community of fellow racing enthusiasts. The shared world elements, such as the ability to challenge other players to impromptu races, add an exciting and unpredictable dimension to the gameplay.

Forza Horizon 4's breathtaking visuals and thrilling gameplay are complemented by a superb soundtrack and radio stations that cater to an array of musical tastes. The audio design, including the roar of engines, the screech of tires, and the satisfying crunch of collisions, adds a layer of realism that enhances the overall immersion.

In conclusion, Forza Horizon 4 is a masterpiece that stands as a testament to the evolution of racing games. Its dynamic seasons, diverse car selection, attention to detail, and seamless blend of single-player and multiplayer experiences make it an absolute must-play for both casual and dedicated racing fans. Playground Games has crafted a virtual automotive playground that's as thrilling as it is visually stunning, earning a resounding 5-star rating without a shadow of doubt.

I've got fairly mixed feelings on this one. I came for NFS heat before this, which had OK visuals, and a terrible story mode...but...I actually enjoyed it. Loved the racing and the nitrous boosts. 

Then I play this...handling and visuals are fantastic. The array of cars is excellent. Not many games have an HSV Maloo, so it was fun to see that being from Austalia. That said, the story and progression are awful. Why I say that is because there's no real point to any of it, even beyond the pointless nature of games. I don't mean that as something existential, its stunning how they could make this with just a "you finished that set of races...here's another set' sort of attitude. 

My map is now peppered with all these races with trophies on them. I'm playing on a Steamdeck, so I can just switch on and off at will, but I can't imagine playing this for 'a session' like I have with other games. Its mind-numbingly pointless, with no other objective other than to race. 

Grid legends and Grid, in contrast, had finish that set of races to get access to the next tier...but you could see the tier sets. This is purely 'surprise' more stuff and to no real end. 

Although that's bad  because it has no objective, if you like 'racing' its delivered with so much polish that most vistas are breathtaking. Upgrades are great, and you can feel the difference. As a 'driving game', purely for driving, I don't think they get much better than this. The controls are sillky smooth (except for some of thos S2 970 cars...I might just be terrible, but I can't control those to save my life). 

For me, that lack of progression just makes the desire to keep playing lacking (that brings the score down quite a bit - it just seems like the devs didn't care for that). Lots of modes though, with racing hovercrafts and the like...that was fun. I'd say its a solid 8/10. It could have been higher if there was focused progression though.

[h1]Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)[/h1]

Forza Horizon 4 is an exceptional racing game that combines stunning visuals, exhilarating gameplay, and an expansive open-world to deliver an unforgettable racing experience. With its diverse and dynamic landscape, robust car selection, and engaging multiplayer features, it stands as a masterpiece in the racing genre.

[h1]Likes:[/h1]

Breathtaking Open-World: Forza Horizon 4's open-world of the United Kingdom is a picturesque and ever-changing playground for racers. The diverse environments, from lush countryside to bustling cities, create a visually stunning and immersive experience.

Dynamic Seasons: The game's dynamic seasonal changes add a unique twist to the gameplay, altering driving conditions and landscapes. Each season brings fresh challenges, making every race feel different and exciting.

Vast Car Selection and Customization: With an extensive roster of cars to choose from, Forza Horizon 4 caters to all driving preferences. The ability to customize and tune cars to suit individual racing styles adds depth to the gameplay.

Immersive Multiplayer Experience: The seamless integration of multiplayer features, such as Forzathon Live events and Horizon Life, fosters a strong sense of community among players. Racing with friends and engaging in cooperative challenges enhances the overall experience.

Outstanding Visuals and Sound Design: The game's visuals are nothing short of breathtaking, with meticulously designed cars and stunning landscapes. The realistic engine sounds and detailed audio effects contribute to the game's immersive atmosphere.

[h1]Dislikes:[/h1]

Limited Customization for Houses: While the game allows players to own properties and houses, some players may wish for more extensive customization options to make their virtual homes more unique.

Occasional Server Issues: During peak times, players may encounter occasional server issues that affect online features. However, the developers have shown dedication to addressing such issues promptly.

In conclusion, Forza Horizon 4 offers an unparalleled racing paradise with its breathtaking open-world, dynamic seasons, and vast car selection. The game's immersive multiplayer features and stunning visuals further elevate the overall experience, making it a must-play for racing enthusiasts and gamers alike. Whether you're a seasoned racing veteran or a newcomer to the genre, Forza Horizon 4 promises an exhilarating journey through a racing wonderland. Buckle up and get ready for an adrenaline-fueled adventure on the roads of the United Kingdom.

Although Forza Horizon 5 has gained more popularity, Forza Horizon 4 remains an exceptional choice However if you have the budget I highly recommend experiencing the latest installment Forza Horizon 5

Things I like:

  months  to be fixed

The last one is the main reason why I do not recommend the game.

If you want a fun, open world driving game with your friends that's cross play with Xbox, Forza Horizon 4 is your go to game. It has everything your standard racing game has in a open world setting, only downside is that the game takes place in the UK. For first time players, before you have access to all the cool challenges to get all the rare cars you see in YouTube videos, you need to complete the first 4 seasons and get your horizon pass. after that its smooth sailing, but even before you do all 4 seasons, you can still do basically anything you want. Though i would recommend you invest in either a controller to play with, or if you wanna play it like its a simulation, get a good Racing Wheel and pedals, and if you wanna try manual shifting, get a shifter. I personally use the Logitech G29 with the pedals and the shifter, and its a blast to play with.

A Thrilling Journey Through Stunning Landscapes

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)

This is an exhilarating open-world racing game that completely blew away my expectations. From the moment I fired up the engine, I was captivated by the jaw-dropping graphics and seamless gameplay, creating an experience that made time disappear as I delved deeper into its virtual world.

Visually, Forza Horizon 4 sets a new standard for racing games. The meticulously designed landscapes are an absolute feast for the eyes, and the attention to detail is simply astonishing. From the lush greenery of the British countryside to the bustling streets of Edinburgh, every corner of this world feels alive and immersive. I found myself stopping on the side of the road just to admire the picturesque scenery, forgetting for a moment that I was supposed to be racing!

The range of cars available is equally impressive. With an extensive collection of vehicles to choose from, each with its own unique characteristics and handling, the game caters to every driving style. Whether I wanted to cruise through the city streets in a sleek supercar or take on off-road challenges with a rugged SUV, Forza Horizon 4 had me covered. The sense of progression and unlocking new cars as I advanced through the game was gratifying, keeping me motivated to explore further.

One of the standout features is the dynamic weather system, which adds an extra layer of challenge and excitement to the races. Navigating through rain, snow, and even thunderstorms not only tests your driving skills but also introduces a level of unpredictability that keeps each race fresh and thrilling. The day-night cycle further enhances the realism, making the world feel alive and ever-changing.

The gameplay in Forza Horizon 4 is smooth as silk. The controls are responsive, making even the most demanding maneuvers feel natural. The variety of events and activities available ensures there's never a dull moment. From traditional races to stunt challenges and everything in between, the game consistently delivers heart-pounding action and adrenaline-pumping excitement.

The online integration is seamless, allowing you to share the open-world experience with other players in real-time. Whether you choose to team up for cooperative challenges or compete head-to-head in adrenaline-fueled races, the multiplayer aspect extends the game's longevity and guarantees endless hours of fun.

While Forza Horizon 4 is not without its minor quirks, such as occasional AI oddities or minor glitches, they are easily overshadowed by the overwhelming positives that the game offers. Its vast and visually stunning world, combined with addictive gameplay, make it one of the best racing games I've ever played.

In conclusion, Forza Horizon 4 is an absolute must-have for racing enthusiasts and casual gamers alike. It offers a breathtakingly beautiful and immersive experience that will keep you coming back for more. Turn the key, buckle up, and get ready for an unforgettable journey through the virtual roads of Great Britain.

When I first played Horizon 4, I was bored to death because of the no career progression system, meaning getting supercars quickly and not going at a slower pace.
But, I decided to look the game from a different point of view.
I have never been a casual game player or sandbox racer fan to be exact. Always wanting to start as an underdog, and climb to the top. 
Since what I do in life for work is all the time since I have my own thing (freelance), I rarely get time to invest in gaming in general.
After spending a couple of relaxing hours, started looking at Horizon from a more positive angle.
Really enjoying the time I spend on it. 

Performance wise :
The game runs perfectly on my PC, medium quality on 60 fps 
AMD Athlon 220GE
Geforce 1050
16GB RAM

At the start it's a fantastic game. It hooks you right in, opportunities come in, bells and whistles chime on with every bit that you do. Your senses are just constantly stimulated. 50 hrs in and it still brilliant, the Lego and fortune island DLCs are really well built. 

150 hrs in the end is stating to get in sight and slowly this creeping feeling starts to come in that now it's becoming a grind. Started playing some PVP and all of a sudden I started hating it. Players push and shove, even go out of the way to kick you off course. Small mistakes like bumping into a wall are met with a slow down penalty - I'm slowed down already by the accident I'm involved in and the game goes on adding 10 seconds of you moving to a crawling 50mph.

200hrs most achievements are done. Nothing else is being announced. The late game shrouded in a saddening silence. And then the kicker - after all those hours you realise that the game is broken. It cannot be completed. I've checked the developers notes for known bugs. The page is 6 months old https://support.forzamotorsport.net/hc/en-us/articles/360001991068-FH4-Known-Issues

The current players have little to no hope that the game will be fixed ever, shunning Microsoft for lack of care for a game that is still sold a full price 4/5 years later. I was lucky enough to get it on a sale period. Abandonment of this game is eminent. The current announcements are now on a loop. There isn't any more involvement of the MS team caring for the game.

250hrs enjoying the last few crumbs of what is left to do. The superstar cards needed a bit of polishing, but it is evident now that the players don't care enough to get that far either. I've spent hours driving about whilst waiting for a Ranked drift adventure, never happened. The creative card is a poor attempt at sharing new creations. Good idea in concept - but a rapidly ageing one. Now its just a grind fest of sharing and unsharing pictures, car mods, liveries, and blue print tracks. Its not racing any more. I'd rather go do unpaid overtime work than this.

Its a shame. This game and its community have been let down so drily, unceremoniously, abandoned, as MS develops the next money grabbing title. The game is worth while, but the late game part is just disappointing. I, like many others will get stuck at 99% achievement completion. It is ironically fitting that the last achievement is called 'Encore?' with  a question mark, because I think I know the answer for that one. 

No

There won't be

Edit: The 'FH4 Known Issues' page has been updated with the following remark: "Latest Nvidia driver causing game to Freeze/Crash (updating to studio driver or rolling back driver solves this issue) [12.1.22] Nvidia Drivers" - Meaning you can't play the game properly unless you have old Nvidia Drivers. Wonderful, just wonderful

Edit2: An update fix has been announced on the 7th of March 2023, that on the 60th Series the Encore Achievement will be functioning as it should. In lieu of this announcement I have downloaded the game again to test out if it is possible to play. The game remains unplayable for Steam buyers that own 30 or 40 Series Nvidia Cards, with forums still recommending downgrading the GPU driver to V522.25 - a 5 month old driver. At the date of writing, my GPU driver is V531.18 which is recommended by most games. This game will still keep its thumbs down vote

Edit 3: I'm at about 700 hrs and I feel it is time to call it here. The game has had its major issues fixed since my last update and I've enjoyed the time I did in this game. It is worth the grind of getting better at the game , get ridiculously rich, get some rival times, customise, and expand you collection of cars. It's fun but I stand firmly that the first 100 hrs are the best ones. At 250 hrs you're at the endgame and probably getting the Encore achievement. I've pushed to 700 hrs because its and easy casual game, but I'm stopping now as there isn't much else to do other then to push further on records or getting more money. All in all it is worth buying the game - there are still some broken features but nothing that will compromise the over all gaming experience. For me this game earns a 7.5/10.

Beautifully made racing game set in Scotland. You can race from the city of Edinburgh to the beaches outside Bamburgh castle upto the Glenfinnan mountains in the North at 170mph+ through Spring, Summer, Autumn & Winter with hundreds of cars to collect, tune, paint and modify to your liking, as well as having hundreds of races and events to take part in either offline or online. Also I'd recommend checking out the Fortune Island and Lego racer dlc packs for some extra content and locations to travel to.
BUY ALL THE DLCS AND HAVE SO MUCH FUN. (including konigesegg agera)

Horrible for PC users.  A Microsoft Game that cannot run on a Microsoft operating system. Constantly freezes up and or crashes sometimes after 15 minutes sometimes after an hour.  Doesn't appear to be a resource issue since I've thrown more than the recommended CPU, Memory, and GPU at it.  Found multiple entries in event viewer and not always consistent,  There is a huge amount of information about issues with this game on PC but solutions are all over the board.  Very frustrating.

Update - Finally decided to go ahead and load older nvidia driver v.522.25 as some have recommended...and Forza 4 has become stable.

Now - I see a new patch was released on April 4 to correct this driver issue....not sure I'm ready to try changing the driver again just yet.  I'm just starting to enjoy Forza 4.

Have been enjoying the level of detail in this simulation and have changed my rating to Recommended.  I still have yet to load the latest nvidia driver though...UPDATE...

Have been running newer versions (currently 535.98) and Forza 4 has been very stable.  Thank you Microsoft.

This is a fantastic open world arcade racing game. The "arcade" driving physics help you get quickly used to driving different kind of cars across different terrains. Driving open-world from race to race in the beautifully created environments is fun. The game is generous with giving cars out at frequent intervals so it never becomes a grind. It's pure fun - highly recommend!

"Forza Horizon 4" received widespread acclaim from both critics and players for several reasons:

Open-World Gameplay: The game is set in a beautiful open-world representation of Great Britain. Players can explore a diverse and expansive map that includes cities, countryside, lakes, and more. The dynamic weather system and seasonal changes add variety and challenge to the driving experience.

Car Selection: "Forza Horizon 4" features an extensive roster of over 700 cars, ranging from classic and modern sports cars to off-road vehicles. Each car is meticulously modeled, offering a wide variety of driving experiences.

Dynamic Seasons: One of the standout features of the game is the dynamic seasonal system. As players progress through the in-game calendar, the seasons change, affecting the driving conditions and the overall look of the world. This adds a new layer of strategy and diversity to the gameplay.

Driving Experience: "Forza Horizon 4" strikes a balance between accessibility and realism, making it enjoyable for both casual players and racing enthusiasts. The driving mechanics feel responsive and rewarding, and the game provides various driving assists that can be adjusted to suit individual preferences.

Online Multiplayer: The game offers seamless online multiplayer, allowing players to join events, races, and challenges with friends or other players from around the world. The shared open-world experience creates a lively and interactive environment.

Stunning Graphics: "Forza Horizon 4" is praised for its stunning graphics and attention to detail. The cars, environments, and visual effects are all top-notch, providing a visually immersive experience.

Regular Updates: Playground Games actively supports "Forza Horizon 4" with regular updates, including new cars, events, and features. This keeps the game fresh and engaging for players over an extended period.

Overall, "Forza Horizon 4" is considered one of the best open-world racing games, offering a perfect blend of realism, exploration, and entertainment.

Update to my review: The game crashes randomly on nVidia cards and nothing has been done by the devs to fix this issue that's been going on for more than 2 years! 

Their solution was to downgrade to the 522 drivers - why the fuck should anyone do this? The devs seem to live in a world where they think people use their PCs to only play one game that is Horizon 4. 

The fact that they haven't come out with a patch or anything to address this issue makes me NOT want to recommend the game in its current state to anyone with nVidia cards.
